questions.text: Needle-shaped crystals negatively birefringent on polarized microscopy is characteristic of which crystal-associated arthropathy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gout

 

Option A)

 

BIREFRINGENT URATE CRYSTALS

 

  • Characteristic negatively birefringent urate crystals in the synovial fluid examined by polarizing microscopy is diagnostic of gout.
  • During acute gouty attack, strongly negatively birefringent needle-shaped mono sodium urate (MSU) crystals are seen (diagnostic).
  • Under polarizing light microscopy, urate crystals are yellow when aligned parallel to the axis of the red compensator and blue when aligned across the direction of polarization i.e., they exhibit negative birefringence.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. CPPD: CPPD, or pseudogout, is characterized by the deposition of calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate crystals in the joints. These crystals are rhomboid-shaped and are positively birefringent under polarized light.

 

Option C. Neuropathic arthropathy: Neuropathic arthropathy is associated with nerve damage, often seen in conditions such as diabetes. It is characterized by joint damage and deformities due to the loss of sensation and proprioception. Crystal deposition is not a typical feature of neuropathic arthropathy.

 

Option D. Hemophilic arthropathy: Hemophilic arthropathy is a condition that affects joints in individuals with hemophilia. It is characterized by recurrent bleeding into the joints, leading to chronic inflammation, synovial hypertrophy, and joint damage. Crystals are not typically associated with hemophilic arthropathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gout is a form of inflammatory arthritis caused by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in the joints.
  • These crystals appear as needle-shaped and are negatively birefringent when viewed under polarized light.

choices.text: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus

questions.text: Joint erosion is not a feature in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Systemic Lupus Erythematosus

 

Option A)

 

JOINT EROSION

 

  • Non-Erosive arthritis - SLE
  • Non-deforming Arthritis - Behçet's syndrome
  • The arthritis of SLE is typically non-erosive.
  • Although the mechanism responsible is unknown, the anti-osteoclastogenic cytokine interferon-alpha (IFN-α), whose transcriptome is present in SLE monocytes, may be responsible. 
  • The arthritis and arthralgias of SLE tend to be migratory; symptoms in a particular joint may be gone within 24 hours but can often last longer.
  • Although any joint can be involved, the arthritis is usually symmetric and polyarticular, with a predilection for the knees, carpal joints, and joints of the fingers, especially the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint.
  • The ankles, elbows, shoulders, and hips are less frequently involved.
  • Involvement of the sacroiliac joints and cervical spine may occur but is rare.
  • Monoarticular arthritis is unusual and suggests an alternative cause such as infection.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Gout. Gout is characterized by the deposition of urate crystals in joints, leading to inflammation. If left untreated and chronic, gout can cause joint damage and erosion over time.

 

Option C. Rheumatoid arthritis.  Joint erosion is a prominent feature of rheumatoid arthritis. Chronic inflammation in RA can lead to the destruction of cartilage and bone in affected joints.

 

Option D. Psoriasis. Psoriatic arthritis, associated with psoriasis, can cause joint damage, including joint erosion. Joint involvement in psoriatic arthritis may lead to erosive changes similar to those seen in rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • While joint involvement can occur in SLE, erosive changes are generally less common compared to conditions like rheumatoid arthritis or psoriatic arthritis.

questions.text: The most commonly involved joint in pseudogout is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Knee

 

Option A)

 

PSEUDOGOUT

 

  • Knee is the commonest affected joint in pseudogout.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Great toe. While pseudogout can affect various joints, the great toe is not the most commonly involved joint. Great toe is most commonly involved in the gout.

 

Option C. Hip. The hip joint can be affected by pseudogout, but it is not the most commonly involved joint.

 

Option D. Elbow. The elbow joint can also be affected by pseudogout, but, similar to the hip, it is not the most commonly involved joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pseudogout can affect various joints, the knee is the most commonly involved joint.
  • The knee joint is often a primary site of crystal deposition and subsequent inflammation in pseudogout.

questions.text: Multiple loose bodies are seen maximum in:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Synovial chondromatosis

 

Option B)

 

LOOSE BODIES

 

  • Causes of loose bodies include:
  1. Osteoarthritis
  2. Osteochondral fracture (injury)
  3. Synovial chondromatosis
  4. Osteochondritis dissecans
  5. Charcot’s disease
  • Among these, osteochondral fracture causes single loose bodies, while all other can cause multiple loose bodies, maximum by synovial chondromatosis (up to hundreds).
  • Osteocartilaginous:
    • These are composed of bone and cartilages hence are detected radiologically.
    • It may originate from:
      • Osteochondritis dissecans (most common cause in young)
      • Osteochondral fracture
      • Osteophyte (osteoarthritis) (most common cause/elderly)
      • Synovial osteochondromatosis.
  • Cartilaginous:
    • Radiolucent loose bodies.
    • Usually are traumatic, cartilaginous and originate from articular surface of tibia, femur or patella.
  • Fibrous:
    • Radiolucent loose bodies.
    • Occur less frequently and result from hyalinized reaction.
    • Originates usually from synovium secondary to trauma, or more commonly from chronic inflammatory condition, such as tuberculosis (rice bodies).
  • Others:
    • lntra-articular tumors such as lipoma and localized nodular synovitis.
    • Bullets, needles, and broken arthroscopic instruments.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Osteochondritis dissecans. This condition involves the separation of a fragment of bone and cartilage from the underlying bone. While it can result in loose bodies, they are typically not numerous.

 

Option C. Osteoarthritis. Osteoarthritis is characterized by the breakdown of cartilage in joints, but it typically doesn't result in multiple loose bodies.

 

Option D. Rheumatoid arthritis. Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune condition that primarily affects the synovial lining of joints. While it can lead to joint damage, it's less likely to result in multiple loose bodies compared to synovial chondromatosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The presence of multiple loose bodies is most commonly associated with synovial chondromatosis.
  • It involves the synovium, the lining of the joint, which undergoes metaplasia and forms cartilaginous nodules that may detach and become free-floating within the joint space.

choices.text: All of the above

questions.text: Epiphyseal enlargement is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Option D)

 

EPIPHYSEAL ENLARGEMENT

 

  • Epiphyseal enlargement refers to an abnormal increase in the size of the epiphysis, which is the rounded end of a long bone that forms part of a joint.
  • This can occur due to various underlying conditions affecting bone development and growth.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Rickets. Rickets is a condition caused by a deficiency of vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate, leading to impaired mineralization of growing bones. In rickets, the epiphyses of the long bones may become enlarged, leading to deformities.

 

Option B. Haemophilia. Hemophilia is a bleeding disorder, and its effects on bones are often related to bleeding into joints, which can lead to joint damage and deformities. Epiphyseal enlargement typical feature of hemophilia.

 

Option C. Septic Arthritis. Septic arthritis is an infection of the joint, and it may lead to destruction of the joint structures. Epiphyseal enlargement is characteristic of septic enlargement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Epiphyseal enlargement refers to an abnormal increase in the size of the epiphysis, which is the rounded end of a long bone that forms part of a joint.
  • Epiphyseal enlargement is seen in rickets, hemophilia and septic arthritis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not affected in gout?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Muscle

 

Option A)

 

GOUT

 

  • Gout primarily involves the joints, where monosodium urate crystals deposit and cause inflammation.
  • The most commonly affected joint is the big toe, but other joints such as the ankles, knees, wrists, and elbows can also be involved.
  • The crystals typically deposit in the synovial fluid within the joint.
  • Pathology:
    • Tophi (= porous stone) are nodular deposits of monosodium urate monohydrate crystals, with an associated foreign body reaction.
    • It is deposited in minute clumps in connective tissue, e.g.
      • Bursae, e.g. olecranon bursa/periarticular tissue
      • Tendons
      • Synovium and joints
      • Pinnae (cartilage) of ear
      • Ligaments
      • Articular ends of bone
      • Subcutaneous tissue
      • Kidney
      • Tophi may ulcerate through skin or destroy cartilage and periarticular bone

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Skin. In advanced cases of gout, tophi may develop under the skin. Tophi are nodular masses composed of urate crystals and can be found in various tissues, including the skin. These tophi can lead to skin changes, such as nodules or lumps, and may be visible or palpable.

 

Option C. Cartilage. Gout can affect cartilage indirectly by causing joint damage. Urate crystals can accumulate in the joints, leading to inflammation and damage to the cartilage over time. Joint erosion and deformities may occur as a result of chronic gout, especially if the condition is not adequately managed. They most commonly affect the cartilage of the ear i.e., the pinna.

 

Option D. Tendon. Tendons around the joints can be affected in gout. Urate crystal deposition in and around the tendons can lead to inflammation, a condition known as tenosynovitis. This inflammation can cause pain, swelling, and difficulty with joint movement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Muscle tissue is not a primary target of urate crystal deposition in gout.
  • The condition can affect the skin (through tophi), cartilage (indirectly causing joint damage), and tendons (leading to tenosynovitis).

questions.text: Calcification of menisci is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pseudogout

 

Option B)

 

PSEUDOGOUT

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hyperparathyroidism. Calcification of menisci can be seen in hyperparathyroidism but pseudogut is the commonest cause.

 

Option C. Renal osteodystrophy. Renal osteodystrophy is a bone disorder that occurs in the context of chronic kidney disease (CKD). It is characterized by abnormalities in bone metabolism and mineralization due to impaired kidney function. While renal osteodystrophy can affect bone density and structure, calcification of the menisci is not a common feature of this condition.

 

Option D. Acromegaly. Acromegaly is a disorder caused by excessive growth hormone production, often due to a pituitary tumor. Calcification of menisci can be seen in acromegaly but it is less common than pseudogout.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Calcification of menisci is seen in pseudogout.
  • It can be seen in hyperthyroidism and acromegaly also but pseudogout is the commonest cause.

choices.text: Bone Ingrowth/overgrowth over the surface of the stem
Mechanical bonding between the stem and bone
Press fitting of the stem in the tight canal
Adhesion between the stem and bone due to adhesive properties of the stem

questions.text: In uncemented arthroplasty of the hip, the stem remains attached to the bone by:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bone ingrowth/overgrowth over the surface of the stem

 

Option A)

 

UNCEMENTED THR

 

  • In uncemented THR, prosthesis is directly inserted into the bone without using cement.
  • After some time, osteo-integration over the prosthesis takes place.
  • In uncemented arthroplasty of the hip, the stem is the part of the hip implant that is inserted into the femur.
  • Uncemented arthroplasty relies on the bone's natural ability to grow and attach to the implant.
  • Bone ingrowth/overgrowth in this context refers to the process by which bone tissue grows into or around the surface of the implant stem.
  • This occurs over time as the body recognizes the implant as a foreign object and initiates a healing response.
  • Special surface treatments on the implant may encourage this bone ingrowth.
  • The bone ingrowth/overgrowth provides stability and fixation for the implant within the bone, effectively anchoring it in place.
  • This integration between the bone and the implant is crucial for the long-term success of the hip replacement, as it helps to distribute forces more evenly and reduces the risk of implant loosening or failure.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Mechanical bonding between the stem and bone. While the concept of mechanical bonding is related to achieving stability between the stem and bone, in uncemented arthroplasty, the primary mechanism is bone ingrowth. Mechanical stability is an important aspect, but it is secondary to achieving biological fixation through bone ingrowth.

 

Option C. Press fitting of the stem in the tight canal. Press fitting involves placing the implant into the bone without using cement, relying on the interference fit between the implant and the bone. While press fitting is a component of uncemented arthroplasty, the long-term stability is mainly achieved through bone ingrowth onto the implant surface.

 

Option D. Adhesion between the stem and bone due to adhesive properties of the stem. Adhesion is not the primary mechanism for fixation in uncemented arthroplasty. The goal is to promote biological fixation through bone ingrowth, where bone tissue grows onto the surface of the implant.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In uncemented hip arthroplasty, the goal is for the bone to grow onto the surface of the implant, creating a stable and durable fixation. This process is known as osseointegration.
  • Bone ingrowth helps provide long-term stability and support for the artificial hip joint.

questions.text: A 58-year-old female patient presents with one-year history of anterior knee pain on climbing stairs. On examination, crepitus was present. There was severe restriction of movements beyond 110 degrees. Examination of hip and back was normal. Diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Osteoarthritis

 

Option A)

 

OSTEOARTHRITIS KNEE

 

  • Pain on weight bearing
  • Mild to moderate effusion
  • Aggravated pain on more activity
  • Relief of pain at rest
  • Reduced range of movement, varus deformity
  • Worse with repetitive bending or stairs
  • Worsening over time
  • Better with ice or anti-inflammatory medication
  • Knee stiffness
  • Knee swelling
  • Decreased ambulatory capacity
  • On physical examination of the knee, with the patient standing, look for periarticular erythema and swelling, quadriceps muscle atrophy, and varus or valgus deformities.
  • Observe gait for signs of pain or abnormal motion of the knee joint that can indicate ligamentous instability.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Psoriatic arthritis. Inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis. Symptoms can involve various joints and may present with pain, swelling, and morning stiffness. Psoriatic arthritis may affect the knees, but other joints, skin, and nails are often involved. X-ray will show joint erosion and new bone formation.

 

Option C. Osteonecrosis. Death of bone tissue due to impaired blood supply. Pain and limited joint mobility are common. X-ray may show normal or non-specific changes.

 

Option D. Gout. Inflammatory arthritis caused by the deposition of urate crystals in joints. Sudden onset of severe pain, swelling, and redness in the affected joint (usually the big toe). X-ray shows joint space narrowing, tophi may be visible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Osteoarthritis of knee commonly presents with symptoms of knee pain, pain on climbing stairs or knee bending, crepitus on knee movement, severe restriction of movement.
  • X-ray findings in OA may include joint space narrowing, osteophyte formation, and subchondral sclerosis.

questions.text: All of the following are radiological features of Rheumatoid arthritis except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fibrous ankylosis

 

Option D)

 

RADIOLOGICAL FEATURES OF RHEUMATOID ARTHRITIS

 

  • There is an evidence of soft tissue swelling and joint effusion.
  • The radiograph shows symmetrical involvement of the affected joints. 
  • There is juxta-articular osteopenia within weeks. 
  • There is loss of articular cartilage and bone erosions, which are noticeable on the radiographs after months.
  • There is narrowing of joint space.
  • There is articular destruction and joint deformity, e.g. subluxation of atlantoaxial and cervical joints. 
  • There is lack of hypertrophic bone changes like sclerosis or osteophyte.
  • In RA, joint destruction and inflammation often lead to bony ankylosis or joint space narrowing, rather than fibrous ankylosis.
  • Fibrous ankylosis is more characteristic of conditions like osteoarthritis or psoriatic arthritis, or can be seen in advanced, untreated RA.
  • Fibrous ankylosis involves the formation of excessive fibrous tissue, limiting joint movement without complete bone fusion.
  • Fibrous ankyloses is not an early or consistent radiological feature, but rather a less and late stage complication.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Decreased Joint space: In RA, joint space narrowing is a common finding due to cartilage destruction and erosion.

 

Option B. Articular Erosion: Erosions of joint surfaces are a hallmark of RA. The inflamed synovium (pannus) invades and erodes the bone, particularly at the "bare areas" where the synovium is not protected by cartilage. These marginal erosions are a key diagnostic criterion.

 

Option C. Periarticular Osteopenia: Periarticular osteopenia, or bone density reduction around affected joints, is commonly seen in RA. It is an early and common finding in RA due to local inflammation and hyperemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Radiographic features of Rheumatoid arthritis are joint space narrowing, articular erosion and periarticular osteopenia.
  • While joint stiffness and ankylosis can occur in RA, the more common form is bony ankylosis rather than fibrous ankylosis.
  • Fibrous ankylosis is less specific and less commonly the end-stage fusion compared to bony ankylosis in RA.
  • A pathological possibility in severe, chronic cases, is not as consistently or uniquely identified as a primary radiological feature compared to the others, and bony ankylosis is a more recognized end-stage radiological finding when fusion occurs.

choices.text: Hyperextension of PIP joints & flexion of DIP joints
Hyperextension of DIP joints & flexion PIP joints
Flexion of DIP joints & Extension at metacarpophalangeal joints
Flexion of DIP joints

questions.text: Boutonniere deformity has:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hyperextension of DIP joints & flexion PIP joints

 

Option B)

 

BOUTONNIERE DEFORMITY

 

  • Boutonniere deformity is the flexion contracture of PIP joints and hyperextension of DIP joints.
  • It is due to rupture of extensor tendon.

 

 

Option A. Hyperextension of PIP joints & flexion of DIP joints. This statement corresponds to the swan neck deformity of the finger seen in RA.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Boutonniere deformity is the flexion contracture of PIP joints and hyperextension of DIP joints. It is due to rupture of extensor tendon.

questions.text:
True about ankylosing spondylitis is/are: 

 

  1. Pain relieves on rest
  2. Association with HLA B-27
  3. Enthesitis may occur
  4. 30% cases have acute posterior uveitis
  5. Cardiac conduction defect may present
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2, 3, 5

 

Option A)

 

ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS

 

  • Clinical presentation:
    • Males are affected more frequently than females (2:1 to 10:1)
    • Age of onset is between 15–25 years (late adolescence and early adulthood).
    • The initial symptom is usually dull pain, insidious in onset, felt deep in lower lumbar or gluteal region, accompanied by low back morning stiffness of up to few hour duration that improves with activity and returns following period of inactivity.
    • Question mark (?) posture is due to hyper-kyphosis of thoracic spine and loss of lumbar lordosis.
    • Cervical spine involvement is usually late and show forward stooping and loss of extension and rotation.
    • Most serious complication of spinal disease is spinal fracture with even minor trauma.
    • The most common extra-articular manifestation is acute anterior uveitis (iridocyclitis) occurring in 30%.
    • Cataract and secondary glaucoma are common sequela.
    • Up to 60% of patients have inflammation of colon or ileum (mostly asymptomatic, only 5–10% develop IBD) 3rd degree heart block, cardiac dysfunction (Aortic incompetence), restrictive lung disease.
    • IgA nephropathy, prostatitis and retroperitoneal fibrosis are other manifestations and may shorten life span.
  • Diagnostic Criteria–Modified New York Criterion:
    • Essential criteria is definite radiographic sacroiliitis.
    • Supporting criteria: one of these three
    1. Inflammatory back pain
    2. Limited chest expansion (<5 cm at 4th ICS) {not a reliable criterion in elderly because of pulmonary disorders}
    3. Limited lumbar spine motion in both sagittal and frontal plane (Schober test/Modified Schober test).
    • Inflammatory back pain is classified if (4/5 are present):
  1. Pain for > 3 months
  2. <40 Years age
  3. Insidious onset
  4. Pain improves with exercise
  5. Pain at night
  • Etiology and Pathogenesis:
    • > 90% of AS patients are HLA-B27 positive whereas only 10% of normal population is HLA-B27 positive.
    • 1–6% of adults inheriting HLA-B27 have been found to have AS.
    • The enthesis, the site of ligamentous attachment to bone is primary site of pathology in AS particularly in pelvis and spine.
    • It is associated with prominent edema of adjacent bone marrow and is characterized by erosive lesions that eventually undergo ossification.
  • Treatment:
    • Phenylbutazone is most effective drug but causes aplastic anemia so reserved for non-responsive cases.
    • Indomethacin is most commonly used NSAID.
    • Sulfasalazine and folic acid antagonist (Mtx) is used for peripheral joints.
    • Anti TNF-α therapy, e.g. infliximab or etanercept are also used.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ankylosing spondylitis is associated with HLA-B27 in > 90% patients.
  • Enthesis of the spine and pelvis is the most common articular manifestation.
  • 30% patients have acute anterior uveitis – the most common extra-articular manifestation.
  • Upto 60% patients have 3rd degree heart block and cardiac dysfunction/aortic incompetence.
  • With rest or a period of inactivity, the pain reappears and worsens.

questions.text:
A burn patient develops claw hand. Joint affected will be:

 

  1. Flexion at proximal interphalangeal joint
  2. Flexion at distal interphalangeal joint
  3. Thumb abduction
  4. Flexion at metacarpophalangeal joint
  5. Extension at metacarpophalangeal joint
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 5

 

Option D)

 

CLAW HAND

 

  • Claw hand has flexion at interphalangeal joints and hyperextension at metacarpophalangeal joints.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post burn, the claw hand developed shows flexion at proximal interphalangeal joint, flexion at distal interphalangeal joint and extension at metacarpophalangeal joint.

choices.text: All are correct

questions.text:
True about reactive arthritis is/are: 

 

  1. Triad of arthritis, Urethritis and Conjunctivitis is seen
  2. Hyperkeratotic lesions on palms & soles are seen
  3. It is related to infections by chlamydia, shigella
  4. Anterior Uveitis is seen
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All are correct

 

Option D)

 

REACTIVE ARTHRITIS/REITER’S SYNDROME

 

  • Reactive arthritis (ReA) is inflammatory arthritis that manifests after several days to weeks after a gastrointestinal or genitourinary infection due to an autoimmune response to infection caused by chlamydia and shigella.
  • Reactive arthritis is relatively rare, and the incidence is more common in adult males in the second and third decades of their life.
  • HLA B27  is positive.
  • HLA-B27 should not be used as a diagnostic tool for a diagnosis of acute ReA.
  • The presence of HLA-B27 is believed to potentiate reactive arthritis by presenting bacterial antigens to T cells, altering self-tolerance of the host immune system, increased TNF-alpha production, promoting the invasion of microbes in the gut, and delayed clearance of causative organisms.
  • Diarrhea caused by the offending agents is usually resolved by the time the patient develops arthritis.
  • ReA can be self-limiting, recurrent, or continuous, and about 20% to 25% of the patients may progress to have chronic articular, ocular, and cardiac complications.
  • On physical examination, sausage-shaped fingers/toes, heel pain, asymmetric oligoarthritis of the lower extremities, SI joint and lumbar spine, conjunctivitis or iritis, urethritis or genital ulcers can be seen.
  • Triad: Arthritis + Conjunctivitis + Urethritis/Cervicitis (In females)
  • Mucocutaneous lesions: Circinate balanitis, Keratoderma blennorrhagicum (Hyper-keratotic lesions on palms and soles)
  • Enthesitis is seen; SI joint is commonly involved
  • Anterior uveitis is seen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Reactive arthritis is an inflammatory arthritis caused by bacterial infection from chlamydia and shigella.
  • It involves a triad of arthritis, urethritis and conjunctivitis, which are classical of this condition.
  • The most common ocular manifestation seen is the anterior uveitis.
  • The most common musculoskeletal manifestations are the oligoarthritis involving the lower extremities, lumbar spine and the SI joint; and enthesitis in the Achilles tendon.
  • The most common dermatological manifestation is the presence of hyperkeratotic lesions on the palms and the soles.

choices.text: Degenerative osteoarthritis of spine
Lumbar canal stenosis

questions.text: A 65-year-old man had H/o of back pain since 3 months. ESR is raised. He also has dorsolumbar tenderness on examination and mild restriction of chest movements. On X-ray, syndesmophytes are present in vertebrae. Diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ankylosing hyperostosis

 

Option C)

 

ANKYLOSING HYPEROSTOSIS

 

  • Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis (DISH) is a spondyloarthropathy also known as Forestier’s disease or ankylosing hyperostosis.
  • It is a non-inflammatory disease, with the principal manifestation being calcification and ossification of spinal ligaments and the entheses.
  • The whole spine may be involved, and bony ankyloses occurs, although the disc spaces and facet joints remain unaffected.
  • In advanced stages, the disease may look like melted candle wax.
  • The calcification and ossification is most common in the right side of the spine.
  • The distinctive radiological feature of DISH is the continuous linear calcification along the anteromedial aspect of the thoracic spine.
  • The disease is usually found in people > 60 years of age, and is extremely rare in people in their 30-40’s.
  • The disease can spread to any joint of the body, affecting the neck, shoulders, ribs, hips, pelvis, knees, ankles, and hands.
  • The disease is not fatal, however some associated complications can lead to death.
  • Complications include paralysis, dysphagia, and pulmonary infections.
  • Although DISH manifests in a similar manner to ankylosing spondylitis, these two are totally separate diseases.
  • Ankylosing spondylitis is a genetic disease with identifiable marks, and affects organs whereas DISH has no indication of a genetic link, and does not affect organs other than the lungs, which is only indirect due to the fusion of the rib cage.
  • The usual complaint in DISH is thoracic spinal pain in around 80% of patients.
  • Morning stiffness is also noticed in almost two-thirds of patients.
  • Increased incidence of dysphagia is also reported in some cases.
  • Calcification and ossification may also be seen at peripheral entheseal sites, including the shoulder, iliac crest, ischial tuberosity, trochanters of the hip, tibial tuberosities, patellae, and bones of the hands and/or feet.
  • Treatment: NSAIDs can be helpful in relieving pain and inflammation associated with DISH.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ankylosing spondylitis. Ankylosing spondylitis is present in young age group. Sacroiliitis is always present. Chest expansion is marked but not reliable in elderly. ESR will be high. Syndesmophytes will be present. Lumbar spine is more commonly involved.

 

Option B. Degenerative osteoarthritis of spine. Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease characterized by the breakdown of cartilage in joints, leading to pain and stiffness. It is more commonly associated with aging and wear and tear on joints. Upper cervical and lumbar spine are more commonly involved and are accompanied with radicular symptoms.

 

Option D. Lumbar canal stenosis. Lumbar canal stenosis involves the narrowing of the spinal canal in the lumbar (lower back) region, which can lead to compression of the spinal cord and nerves. Symptoms may include back pain, leg pain, and neurogenic claudication (pain and weakness in the legs during walking). While lumbar canal stenosis can cause back pain, the presence of syndesmophytes and the inflammatory nature of the symptoms in the given case make ankylosing hyperostosis a more relevant diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given complaints of the patient of increased ESR, dosrolumbar region pain and tenderness with mildly restricted chest movements and, the elder age group of the patient are suggestive of presence of ankylosing hyperostosis, which is different from ankylosing spondylitis.

questions.text: Pencil-in-cup deformity is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Psoriatic arthritis

 

Option D)

 

PENCIL-IN-CUP DEFORMITY

 

  • DIP joint involvement in psoriatic arthritis presents as pencil-in-cup deformity on the x-ray of the hands.
  • However, it is not pathognomonic of psoriatic arthritis.
  • The appearance results from periarticular erosions and bone resorption.

 

 

  • Although classically described with psoriatic arthritis, this appearance can also be seen in:
    • rheumatoid arthritis
    • reactive arthritis
    • Behçet disease

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Rheumatoid arthritis. Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic autoimmune disease that primarily affects the joints. The "pencil-in-cup" deformity is not a classic feature of RA. Instead, RA is often associated with joint erosions, synovial inflammation, and deformities like ulnar deviation of the digits with radial deviation of the wrist, swan neck deformity, boutonniere deformity of the fingers.

 

 

Option B. Ankylosing spondylitis. Ankylosing spondylitis is a type of inflammatory arthritis that mainly affects the spine. The hands are not commonly involved in ankylosing spondylitis. Deformities like bamboo spine, dagger sign, trolley track sign are seen in the spine in the advanced stages of the disease.

 

 

 

a. Trolley track sign; b. Bamboo spine; c. Dagger sign

 

Option C. AVN. Avascular necrosis is the death of bone tissue due to a lack of blood supply. It can occur in various joints. AVN is typically associated with bone collapse and joint destruction. With the advancement of the necrosis, flattening of the femoral head can become evident on a plain radiograph.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The "pencil-in-cup" deformity is a classic radiological finding in psoriatic arthritis.
  • It refers to erosive changes at the joint margins, resembling a pencil eroding into the cup-like joint space.

choices.text: Ankylosis of small joints
Lengthening of digits called as telescoping

questions.text: All are true regarding psoriatic arthritis except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lengthening of digit known as telescoping

 

Option D)

 

PSORIATIC ARTHRITIS

  • There is shortening of digits (not lengthening).
  • Clinical Features:
    • Sex ratio is 1:1 and usual age of onset is 30–50 years.
    • Five patterns of joint involvement are seen:
      • Arthritis of DIP joint
      • Asymmetrical oligoarthritis
      • Symmetrical polyarthritis similar to RA
      • Axial involvement (spine and sacroiliac joint)
      • Arthritis mutilans

 

 

  • Nail changes occurs in 90% patients of psoriatic arthritis (40% in patient without arthritis).
  • Dactylitis, enthesitis and tenosynovitis are also common.
  • Shortening of digits (telescoping), because of underlying osteolysis is characteristic of psoriatic arthritis.
  • Fibrous and bony ankylosis of small joints (greater tendency than RA).
  • Almost any peripheral joint can be involved.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Arthritis mutilans. It is a rare form of inflammatory arthritis that causes severe damage to joints and bone tissue. It most commonly develops in people with psoriatic arthritis. 

 

Option B. DIP involvement. Psoriatic arthritis is known for staring at the DIP joints, which are the points closest to the fingernails and toenails.

 

Option C. Ankylosis of small joints. Psoriatic arthritis can lead to ankylosis, which is the fusion of bones in a joint, especially in the small joints of the hands and feet.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The statement which is incorrect about psoriatic arthritis is lengthening of digits known as telescoping.
  • Psoriatic arthritis is associated with shortening of digits, known as telescoping.
  • This occurs due to osteolysis of the bone due to inflammation.

questions.text: Most common muscle for pseudotumor-like growth in hemophiliac arthropathy is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Iliopsoas

 

Option D)

 

HEMOPHILIAC ARTHROPATHY

 

  • Pseudotumor refers to progressive cystic swelling caused by uncontrolled hemorrhage within confined space.
  • The hematoma increases in size and causes pressure necrosis and erosion of bone (mimicking tumor).
  • It occurs in severe hemophiliacs only (clotting factor <1% of normal).
  • Most hemophilic pseudotumors are caused by subperiosteal hemorrhage and the most common location is in thigh (50%).
  • Next in frequency are abdomen, pelvis, and tibia.
  • Iliopsoas is most common muscle involved followed by Quadriceps.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Quadriceps femoris. The quadriceps femoris is a group of four muscles located at the front of the thigh. In hemophilic arthropathy, chronic bleeding into the quadriceps muscles can lead to the formation of pseudotumor-like growths, causing swelling and deformities in the affected area. This is the second most commonly involved muscle after iliopsoas from pseudotumors.

 

Option B. Hamstring muscle and Option C. Gastrocnemius are not commonly involved in pseudotumor in hemophilic arthropathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The iliopsoas is a group of muscles that includes the psoas major, psoas minor, and iliacus, and it is located in the hip region.
  • Pseudotumor-like growths are most commonly seen in the iliopsoas muscles in hemophiliac arthropathy.
  • Note: Iliopsoas > Quadriceps femoris

choices.text: End stage tuberculous joints
Associated with trauma

questions.text: Clutton’s joints are:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Syphilitic joints

 

Option A)

 

SKELETAL MANIFESTATION OF CONGENITAL SYPHILIS

 

  • Clutton’s joint is painless, symmetrical, sterile effusion mostly involving knee in 8–16 years of age. Spontaneous remission is usual in several weeks.
  • Parrot’s joints is effusion, epiphysitis and epiphyseal separation.
  • Higoumenakis' sign, i.e. periostitis with unilateral or bilateral enlargement of sternal end of clavicle.
  • Saber tibia is anterior bowing of midportion of tibia because of subperiosteal apposition of bone on anterior cortical surface.
  • Scaphoid scapula
  • Widened, ill-defined and irregular physis; uninvolved epiphysis and characteristic bilateral and symmetrical metaphyseal erosions and fractures.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. End stage tuberculous joints. Clutton’s joints are effusion joints that are sterile and non-tubercular.

 

Option C. Associated with trauma. Clutton's joints are not associated with trauma. They are associated with congenital syphilis.

 

Option D. Usually painful. This statement is false. Clutton's joints are usually painless. They are characterized by symmetrical effusions in the knee joints that are not accompanied by significant pain. The absence of pain is a key characteristic that helps differentiate Clutton's joints from other joint conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Clutton's joints are associated with syphilis.
  • Syphilis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum.
  • In the context of syphilis, Clutton's joints refer to painless effusions, particularly involving the knee joints.

questions.text: Drug of choice for the treatment of acute gout in patients in whom NSAIDs are contraindicated is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Colchicine

 

Option A)

 

ACUTE GOUT TREATMENT

 

  • Mainstay of treatment during acute attack is administration of anti-inflammatory drug such as colchicine, NSAIDs (except aspirin) or glucocorticoids.
  • NSAIDs and colchicine may be toxic in elderly particularly in renal insufficiency and GI disorders. So, glucocorticoids may be preferred.
  • Resting joint, ice packs, losing weight, decreasing alcohol, eliminating diuretics, low purine diet and increase in liquid ingestion may be preventive.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Allopurinol. Allopurinol is not typically used for the treatment of acute gout attacks. It is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor and is primarily used for long-term management to lower uric acid levels in the blood, preventing the formation of urate crystals. Allopurinol is more commonly indicated for chronic gout treatment rather than for immediate relief during an acute attack.

 

Option C. Xyloric acid. Xyloric acid is not typically used for the treatment of acute gout attack.

 

Option D. Paracetamol. Paracetamol (acetaminophen) is a pain reliever but is generally not the first-line choice for the treatment of acute gout attacks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Colchicine is an anti-inflammatory medication that is effective in the treatment of acute gout attacks.
  • It works by inhibiting the inflammatory response to urate crystals, reducing pain and inflammation.
  • Colchicine is commonly used when NSAIDs are contraindicated or not well-tolerated.

choices.text: Abrupt increase in serum urate levels is a more common cause for acute gout than an abrupt fall in urate levels
Patient may be asymptomatic with high serum uric acid for years
Development of arthritis correlates with level of serum uric acid
Uric acid crystals are best seen by polarizing light microscope

questions.text: What is not true about gout?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Abrupt increase in serum urate levels is a more common cause for acute gout than an abrupt fall in urate levels

 

Option A)

 

GOUT

 

  • Fall of uric acid levels is more commonly associated with acute attack of gout.
  • The risk of developing clinical features of gout increases with increasing levels of serum uric acid, only a fraction of those with hyperuricemia develop symptoms.
  • Any factor that causes either an abrupt increase or decrease in the serum urate levels may provoke an acute attack, the best correlations being factors that cause an abrupt fall.
  • Serum uric acid levels can be normal or low at the time of acute attack, lowering of uric acid with hypouricemic therapy or other medications limits the value of serum uric acid determination for diagnosis of gout.
  • Despite these limitations, serum uric acid is almost always elevated at some time and can be used to follow the course of hypouricemic therapy.
  • Hyperuricemia is present at some stage, though not necessarily during acute attack.
  • However, whilst a low serum uric acid level makes gout unlikely; hyperuricemia is not diagnostic and is often seen in normal middle aged men.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Patient may be asymptomatic with high serum uric acid for years. Patients with elevated serum uric acid levels may remain asymptomatic for years before experiencing their first gout attack. Not everyone with hyperuricemia develops gout, and factors such as genetics, diet, and comorbidities play a role in the manifestation of gout.

 

Option C. Development of arthritis correlates with level of serum uric acid. There is a correlation between the development of arthritis in gout and the level of serum uric acid. Higher levels of serum uric acid increase the risk of urate crystal deposition in joints, leading to gouty arthritis.

 

Option D. Uric acid crystals are best seen by polarizing light microscope. Uric acid crystals are best visualized under a polarizing light microscope, where they appear as needle-shaped crystals with negative birefringence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • An abrupt fall in serum urate levels, which can occur due to factors like rapid initiation of urate-lowering therapy, is more commonly associated with acute gout attacks.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with urine darkening on standing, joint stiffness, and pigment deposition in joints. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Alkaptonuria

 

Option C)

 

ALKAPTONURIA

 

  • It is a heritable metabolic disorder characterized by the appearance of homogentisic acid in urine, dark pigmentation of the connective tissues (ochronosis) and calcification of hyaline and fibrocartilage.
  • Inborn error is the absence of homogentisic acid oxidase in the liver and kidney.
  • Those affected usually remain asymptomatic until the 3rd and 4th decade when they present with pain and stiffness of the spine and later, larger joints.
  • Dark pigmentation of ear cartilage and sclera and staining of clothes by homogentisic acid in sweat.
  • Urine turns dark brown when it is alkalinized or if it is left to stand for some hours.
  • X-ray reveal narrowing and calcification of inter vertebral discs.
  • Peripheral joints show chondrocalcinosis and severe osteoarthritis.
  • Treatment is with Vitamin C.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Phenylketonuria. Phenylketonuria is a genetic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase, leading to the accumulation of phenylalanine in the blood. If not managed early, it can result in intellectual disabilities. Reduced Tyr can cause decreased melanin synthesis and light skin and hair. Signs and symptoms of the disease that become more pronounced when untreated include delayed developmental milestones, microcephaly, hypopigmentation, hyperactivity/behavior problems, seizures, and a musty odor to skin and urine. PKU is not associated with urine darkening on standing or pigment deposition in joints.

 

Option B. Tyrosinemia. Tyrosinemia is a group of rare genetic disorders characterized by the accumulation of tyrosine in the body. There are different types of tyrosinemia, and they can affect the liver, kidneys, and nervous system. However, like PKU, tyrosinemia is not typically associated with urine darkening or pigment deposition in joints.

 

Option D. Hemosiderin deposition. Hemosiderin is a pigment derived from hemoglobin breakdown and is typically seen in conditions involving chronic bleeding or iron overload. While hemosiderin deposition can cause discoloration of tissues, it's less likely to present with urine darkening and joint stiffness compared to alkaptonuria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Alkaptonuria is a rare metabolic disorder characterized by the deficiency of the enzyme homogentisate 1,2-dioxygenase, leading to the accumulation of homogentisic acid.
  • This acid, when exposed to air, darkens and causes urine to turn dark upon standing.

choices.text: CPPD crystals under microscope
Polyarthritis with urinary sediment

questions.text: The pathognomonic finding in pseudogout is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CPPD crystals under microscope

 

Option A)

 

PSEUDOGOUT

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Polyarthritis with urinary sediment. Polyarthritis refers to inflammation affecting multiple joints. However, urinary sediment is not a characteristic finding of pseudogout. Instead, it may be more associated with conditions like systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) or other autoimmune disorders.

 

Option C. Juxta-articular osteopenia. Juxta-articular osteopenia, or decreased bone density near joints, is not a pathognomonic finding for pseudogout. It may be seen in various joint conditions, including inflammatory arthritis, but it is not specific to pseudogout.

 

Option D. Bone spurs. Bone spurs, also known as osteophytes, are bony outgrowths that can develop on the edges of joints. While pseudogout can contribute to joint damage and degeneration, the presence of bone spurs is not pathognomonic for pseudogout.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pseudogout, or calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition disease (CPPD), is characterized by the deposition of calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate crystals in the joints.
  • These crystals are rhomboid-shaped and exhibit positive birefringence under polarized light microscopy.
  • The identification of CPPD crystals in synovial fluid is a key diagnostic feature of pseudogout.

questions.text: Chondrocalcinosis is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ochronosis

 

Option A)

 

CHONDROCALCINOSIS

 

  • Chondrocalcinosis is the deposition of calcium containing salts in articular cartilage.

 

 

  • It is found in:
    • Pseudogout (CPPD) – most important
    • Alkaptonuria (ochronosis)
    • Hemochromatosis
    • Hyperparathyroidism
    • Hypothyroidism
    • Acromegaly
    • Diabetes mellitus
    • Wilson’s disease
    • Gout

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Hypoparathyroidism. Hyperparathyroidism and not hypoparathyroidism is associated with chondrocalcinosis.

 

Option C. Rickets. Rickets is a condition primarily associated with vitamin D deficiency or impaired vitamin D metabolism, leading to problems with bone mineralization. Chondrocalcinosis is not a characteristic feature of rickets.

 

Option D. Hypervitaminosis. Hypervitaminosis refers to excessive intake of vitamins. While excessive vitamin intake can have various effects on the body, chondrocalcinosis is not a typical manifestation of hypervitaminosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chondorocalcinosis or the deposition of calcium salt in the articular cartilage is associated with pseudogout most commonly, followed by alkaptonuria.

questions.text:
Choose the correct statement about articular cartilage. 

 

  1. Zone 2 contains articular cartilage progenitor cell
  2. Zone 4 contains calcified cartilage
  3. Zone 3 has highest proteoglycans content
  4. Zone 1 has high water content
  5. Zone 3 has chondrocytes in low density
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2, 3, 4

 

Option A)

 

ZONES OF ARTICULAR CARTILAGE

 

  • There are four zones (layers) of articular cartilage from the articular surface to subchondral bone.

 

 

Explanation:

 

  1. Zone 2 contains articular cartilage progenitor cells: False. The progenitor cells are found in the zone 1 of the articular cartilage. 
  2. Zone 4 contains calcified cartilage: True. The zone 4 of the articular cartilage is called the calcified or tidemark zone because at this zone, the articular cartilage is calcified and provides the structural support. The calcified zone is located deepest, separating the deep zone from the subchondral bone.
  3. Zone 3 has highest proteoglycans content: True. The deep zone (Zone 3) has the highest proteoglycan content as well as the lowest water concentration.
  4. Zone 1 has high water content: True. Zone 1 has the higher amount of water (around 80%) and collagen content. Water content generally decreases from the superficial to the deep zones.
  5. Zone 3 has chondrocytes in low density: False. The superficial zone (Zone 1) generally has the highest density of flattened chondrocytes. The middle (Zone 2) zone typically have a lower density of chondrocytes, which are more rounded and often arranged in columns in the deep zone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Zone 1 contains articular cartilage progenitor cells.
  • Zone 4 contains calcified cartilage. 
  • Zone 3 has highest proteoglycans content. 
  • Zone 1 has high water content. 
  • Zone 2 has lower chondrocyte density.

questions.text: Synovial fluid of low viscosity is seen in all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Osteoarthritis

 

Option C)

 

SYNOVIAL FLUIDS VISCOSITY

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Gout, Option B. Septic arthritis, and Option D. Rheumatoid arthritis are characterized by decreased viscosity of the synovial fluid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Low viscosity of synovial fluid is seen in Rheumatic fever, Rheumatic arthritis, gout, Pyogenic arthritis, Tubercular arthritis.
  • Osteoarthritis is normal synovial fluid viscosity.

choices.text: Inflammation of synovial joints
Most common disease of joints
Affects shoulder joint
Narrowing of the joint space occurs

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about osteoarthritis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inflammation of synovial joints

 

Option A)

 

OSTEOARTHRITIS

 

  • Inflammation is less prominent in osteoarthritis.
  • It is mainly seen in rheumatoid arthritis, crystal arthritis etc.
  • Osteoarthritis is mainly characterized by age-related mechanical degeneration of articular cartilage and new bone formation in the form of osteophytes and osteosclerosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Most common disease of joints. True. Osteoarthritis is indeed the most common joint disorder. It affects millions of people worldwide, especially as they age. The degeneration of joint cartilage and changes in underlying bone are characteristic features.

 

Option C. Affects shoulder joint. True. While osteoarthritis is more commonly associated with weight-bearing joints like the knees and hips, it can affect any joint in the body, including the shoulder. In the shoulder joint, osteoarthritis may lead to pain, stiffness, and reduced range of motion.

 

Option D. Narrowing of the joint space. True. Radiographically, osteoarthritis is characterized by the narrowing of the joint space. As the cartilage in the joint wears away, the space between the bones decreases. This narrowing is a hallmark feature seen on X-rays in individuals with osteoarthritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Osteoarthritis is primarily characterized by degeneration of the joint cartilage and changes in the underlying bone.
  • Unlike rheumatoid arthritis, osteoarthritis is not characterized by significant inflammation of the synovial membrane.
  • Instead, it involves a more gradual and wear-and-tear type of joint damage.

choices.text: Very vascular structure
Surrounded by thick perichondrium
Has no nerve supply

questions.text: What is true about Articular cartilage?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Has no nerve supply

 

Option C)

 

ARTICULAR CARTILAGE

 

  • Articular cartilage is the highly specialized connective tissue of diarthrodial joints.
  • Its principal function is to provide a smooth, lubricated surface for articulation and to facilitate the transmission of loads with a low frictional coefficient.
  • Articular cartilage is devoid of blood vessels, lymphatics, and nerves and is subject to a harsh biomechanical environment.
  • Most important, articular cartilage has a limited capacity for intrinsic healing and repair. 
  • Structure and Composition of Articular Cartilage:
    • Articular cartilage is a 2 to 4 mm thick hyaline cartilage.
    • Articular cartilage does not have blood vessels, nerves, or lymphatics.
    • It is composed of a dense extracellular matrix (ECM) with sparse highly specialized cells called chondrocytes.
    • The ECM is principally composed of water, collagen, and proteoglycans, with other non-collagenous proteins and glycoproteins in lesser amounts. 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Very vascular structure. False. Articular cartilage is avascular i.e., it lacks blood vessels. It relies on diffusion from the synovial fluid to obtain nutrients and oxygen. The absence of blood vessels contributes to the limited regenerative capacity of articular cartilage.

 

Option B. Surrounded by thick perichondrium. False. Articular cartilage does not have a perichondrium. Perichondrium is a dense connective tissue layer that surrounds most cartilage types, but articular cartilage lacks this outer layer. This absence contributes to the limited ability of articular cartilage to repair and regenerate.

 

Option D. Fibrocartilage. False. Articular cartilage is predominantly hyaline cartilage, not fibrocartilage. Fibrocartilage is a different type of cartilage that contains more collagen fibres and is found in structures like the intervertebral discs and certain joint structures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Articular cartilage is avascular and aneural i.e., it lacks blood vessels and nerves.

questions.text: CASPAR criteria is used in diagnosis of:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Psoriatic arthritis

 

Option A)

 

CASPAR CRITERIA FOR PSORIATIC ARTHRITIS

 

  • To be classified as having Psoriatic Arthritis, a patient must have inflammatory joint disease (joint, spine, enthesitis) with ≥ 3 of the following 5:
  1. Evidence of psoriasis (one of these):
    • Current psoriasis
    • Personal history
    • Family history
  2. Psoriatic nail dystrophy (onycholysis, pitting, hyperkeratosis)
  3. Negative rheumatoid factor
  4. Dactylitis (either current psoriasis or personal history)
  5. Radiological evidence of juxta-articular new bone formation

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Rheumatoid arthritis. Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic autoimmune disease that primarily affects the joints, causing inflammation, pain, and joint damage. Diagnosis of RA is based on clinical features, laboratory tests (such as rheumatoid factor and anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibodies), and imaging studies. The 1987 ACR/EULAR classification criteria is used for RA diagnosis. It requires presence of at least 4 out of 7 symptoms for at least 3 months.

  1. Morning stiffness, in and around joint lasting 1 hour before maximal improvement.
  2. Arthritis of 3 or more joint areas, observed by a physician simultaneously, have soft tissue swelling or joint effusion, not just bony over growth. The 14 possible joint areas involved are right or left PIP, MCP, wrist, elbow, knee, ankle and MTP joints.
  3. Arthritis of hand joints, e.g. wrist, MP or PIP joints.
  4. Symmetrical arthritis.
  5. Rheumatoid nodules (Pathognomonic): Subcutaneous nodules over bony prominences, extensor surfaces or juxta-articular region.
  6. Serum rheumatoid factor.
  7. Radiological changes: bony erosion or unequivocal bony decalcification, periarticular osteoporosis and narrowing of articular (joint) space.

 

Option C. Ankylosing spondylitis. Ankylosing spondylitis (AS) is a type of inflammatory arthritis that mainly affects the spine, causing stiffness, pain, and eventually fusion of the vertebrae. Diagnosis of AS involves clinical features, imaging studies (like X-rays showing syndesmophytes), and sometimes blood tests. A diagnosis of AS can usually be confirmed if an X-ray shows sacroiliitis and there is at least 1 of the following:

 

  1. at least 3 months of lower back pain that gets better with exercise and doesn't improve with rest
  2. limited movement in lumbar spine
  3. limited chest expansion compared

 

Option D. Reactive synovitis. Reactive synovitis refers to inflammation of the synovial membrane in response to an infection elsewhere in the body, often in the gastrointestinal or genitourinary tract. It is not a specific term used for a well-defined rheumatological condition. Diagnosis involves assessing the clinical context, including symptoms and potential triggers of the inflammation. According to American College of Rheumatology, there are 2 major and 2 minor diagnostic guidelines of reactive arthritis. Major guidelines includes asymmetric oligo or monoarthritis involving lower extremities, and either enteritis or urethritis symptoms preceding the onset of arthritis by a time interval of 3 days to 6 weeks. Minor guidelines includes presence of a triggering infection as evidenced by culture positivity, and presence of persistent synovial involvement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Psoriatic arthritis is an inflammatory arthritis that occurs in some individuals with psoriasis, a chronic skin condition characterized by red, scaly patches on the skin.
  • CASPAR criteria (Classification Criteria for Psoriatic Arthritis) include the presence of inflammatory articular disease (joint involvement), along with points for other features such as psoriasis, nail changes, family history, and negative tests for rheumatoid factor.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male underwent total hip replacement surgery due to severe osteoarthritis. The surgery went uneventful, but on 3rd post-operative day, he started complaining of breathlessness which worsens on increase in activity, chest discomfort. Lab investigations reveals raised d-dimer levels. What is the definitive management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thrombolysis

 

Option A)

 

  • Thromboembolic disease (TED) is one of the most common serious complication of THR.
  • The 30-day mortality rate from pulmonary embolism in patients undergoing elective THR was 0.04%, behind myocardial infarction (MI) and cardiorespiratory arrest.
  • The given clinical scenario is suggestive of pulmonary thromboembolism (THR surgery + 3rd day breathlessness + raised d-dimer levels).
  • Definitive treatment of Pulmonary thromboembolism in an unstable patient is Systemic thrombolysis (Anticoagulation therapy in a stable patient.)
  • Pulmonary thromboembolism is characterized by obstruction of main pulmonary artery or its branches by a thrombus which was originated elsewhere.
  • It results in V/Q mismatch due to sufficient ventilation but no perfusion.
  • Clinically, the patient presents with pleuritic chest pain, dyspnea which increases on exertion, tachypnea, tachycardia.
  • Screening is done by evaluating the D-dimer levels.
  • IOC: CECT Chest or CTPA
  • ECG shows sinus tachycardia (most common), S1Q3T3 (most specific).
  • Echocardiography shows McConell Sign (RV hypokinesia, hyperkinetic apex).
  • Chest X-ray shows Hampton Hump sign (wedge-shaped opacity), Palla sign (prominent right descending pulmonary artery), Westermark sign (increased lucency due to focal oligemia).
  • Treatment – Anticoagulation therapy (Heparin, direct thrombin/Factor Xa inhibitors).
  • If Anticoagulation is contraindicated, IVC filter may be used.
  • If patient is unstable, perform systemic thrombolysis.
  • If thrombolysis is C/I, Mechanical embolectomy should be done.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Bronchodilators. Bronchodilators are primarily used in conditions such as asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) to relieve airway constriction. In the context of a pulmonary embolism, bronchodilators would not be the first-line treatment, as the primary issue is a blood clot affecting blood flow to the lungs.

 

Option C. Steroids. Steroids are generally not the primary treatment for a pulmonary embolism. They would not address the underlying cause of the symptoms, which is likely a blood clot. Steroids might be used for certain inflammatory conditions but are not indicated as a definitive treatment for pulmonary embolism.

 

Options D. Oxygen. Oxygen is often given to patients experiencing breathlessness or hypoxia (low oxygen levels). While providing oxygen can support the patient's respiratory function, it does not directly address the underlying cause of a pulmonary embolism. Oxygen is supportive care and is often used while other definitive treatments, such as anticoagulation, are initiated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Thrombolysis is commonly used in cases of severe pulmonary embolism where there is a significant compromise of blood flow to the lungs.
  • Thrombolysis aims to rapidly break down the clot and restore normal blood circulation.

questions.text: In OA, one of this is beneficial:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glucosamine

 

Option A)

 

OSTEOARTHRITIS

 

Classification system and stage wise management for OA knee:

 

  1. Initial treatment is always conservative, exercise and glucosamines are preferred.
  2. Clinical picture is more significant than radiology or X-ray changes.
  3. If activities of daily living are affected, surgery is advised.
  4. Surgery for young is HTO if not contraindicated. If contraindicated, TKR is performed.
  5. Surgery for elderly (≥ 65 years) is TKR.
  6. High Tibial Osteotomy
  7. Total Knee Replacement
  8. Usually, stage 2 onwards in elderly, TKR is finally carried out.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Ketones. Ketones are organic compounds produced when the body breaks down fat for energy in the absence of sufficient glucose. Ketones are not typically associated with direct benefits in osteoarthritis.

 

Option C. Glucose. It is a simple sugar and a primary source of energy for the body. While maintaining stable blood glucose levels is important for overall health, glucose itself is not specifically considered a treatment or beneficial intervention for osteoarthritis.

 

Option D. Citric acid. Citric acid is a weak organic acid found in citrus fruits. Citric acid is not typically associated with direct benefits in osteoarthritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Glucosamine is a natural compound found in the body, particularly in the fluid that surrounds the joints.
  • It is commonly taken as a dietary supplement.
  • It helps to reduce pain and improve function in individuals with osteoarthritis.

choices.text: It is a type of elastic cartilage
It is hyaline cartilage on the articular surface of bones
It is type 1 cartilage providing compressive strength
It is hyaline cartilage found in growth plate of bones

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about Articular Cartilage?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is hyaline cartilage on the articular surface of bones

 

Option B)

 

ARTICULAR CARTILAGE

 

  • Articular cartilage is a specialized type of hyaline cartilage that covers the articulating surfaces of bones or ends of the synovial joints.
  • This cartilage helps in reducing friction and absorbing shock during joint movements.
  • It is smooth and slippery, allowing for smooth movement between bones in a joint.
  • It does not contain blood vessels, nerves, or lymphatics, and obtains nutrition through diffusion.
  • Articular cartilage is made of type II collagen.
  • It is divided into four zones:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Is a type of elastic cartilage. Articular cartilage is not a type of elastic cartilage. Elastic cartilage contains more elastic fibres and is found in structures like the external ear and epiglottis. Articular cartilage is predominantly hyaline cartilage.

 

Option C. Is type 1 cartilage providing compressive strength. Articular cartilage provides a smooth and low-friction surface for joint movement.

 

Option D. Is hyaline cartilage found in growth plate of bone. The hyaline cartilage found in the growth plate (epiphyseal plate) of bones is a different type of cartilage. It is involved in longitudinal bone growth and is eventually replaced by bone tissue as a person reaches skeletal maturity. Articular cartilage is found at the articulating surface of the joints.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The statement true about articular cartilage is that it is hyaline cartilage on the articular surface of bones.
  • It is not an elastic cartilage.
  • It provides smooth surface at the joint for movements.

questions.text: Nutrient and oxygen reach the chondrocytes across perichondrium by:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Diffusion

 

Option B)

 

PERICHONDRIUM

 

  • Chondrocytes are the cells found in cartilage tissue.
  • Cartilage is an avascular structure.
  • Therefore, the nutrients and oxygen needed by chondrocytes must diffuse through the surrounding matrix to reach them.
  • The perichondrium is a layer of connective tissue that surrounds cartilage in many areas.
  • The perichondrium itself contains blood vessels but they do not penetrate deep into the cartilage.
  • So, the nutrients and oxygen diffuse through the matrix of the cartilage from the nearby blood vessels in the perichondrium to reach the chondrocytes.
  • Thus, diffusion process is essential for the maintenance and function of cartilage cells in avascular environments.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Capillaries. Capillaries are small blood vessels that bring nutrients and oxygen to tissues. In the context of cartilage, the perichondrium is vascularized with capillaries.

 

Option C. Along Neurons. Neurons are not the primary means by which nutrients and oxygen are transported to chondrocytes.

 

Option D. Active transport. Active transport is a cellular process that requires energy to move molecules against their concentration gradient. In the context of nutrient and oxygen supply to chondrocytes, passive processes like diffusion is more relevant.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Diffusion is a process by which molecules move from an area of higher concentration to an area of lower concentration.
  • Since articular cartilage is an avascular structure, it gets its nutrients from the blood supply of the perichondrium.
  • So nutrients and oxygen reach the chondrocytes across perichondrium by the process of diffusion.

choices.text: Lupus Arthritis/Jaccoud arthritis

questions.text: All of the following cause erosive arthritis except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lupus arthritis/Jaccoud arthritis

 

Option B)

 

EROSIVE ARTHRITIS

 

  • Non-Erosive arthritis - SLE
  • Non-deforming Arthritis - Behçet's syndrome
  • Erosive arthritis is a type of arthritis where joint damage occurs, often leading to erosion of the bone and cartilage within the joint.
  • The conditions causing erosive arthritis are:
    • Rheumatoid arthritis
    • Tuberculous arthritis
    • Septic arthritis
    • Erosive osteoarthritis
    • Psoriatic arthritis
    • Reactive arthritis
    • Ankylosing spondylitis
    • Gout
    • Neuropathic arthropathy

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Rheumatoid arthritis. Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic autoimmune disorder that primarily affects the joints. Rheumatoid Arthritis is known for causing erosive arthritis, as chronic inflammation in the synovium leads to the destruction of cartilage and bone within the joints.

 

Option C. Tuberculous arthritis. Tuberculous arthritis, caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, can lead to joint destruction. It can cause erosive arthritis.

 

Option D. Septic arthritis. Septic arthritis is caused by a bacterial infection within a joint, leading to inflammation and potential joint damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lupus Arthritis/Jaccoud arthritis does not cause erosive arthritis.
  • Lupus arthritis, also known as Jaccoud arthritis, is a form of arthritis associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), an autoimmune disease.
  • Jaccoud arthritis is generally considered non-erosive inflammatory arthritis.
  • It involves joint deformities that are reversible and does not typically result in the erosive changes.

choices.text: Acute pyogenic arthritis

questions.text: In the examination of synovium aspirate of a patient with arthritis, numerous lymphocytes, plasma cells and histiocytes are found. What type of arthritis is it?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Granulomatous arthritis

 

Option C)

 

ARTHRITIS

 

  • Synovial fluid in different types of arthritis:
  1. Normal synovial fluid is clear, WBC count ≤ 200/ mL
  2. Non-inflammatory synovial fluid is clear, viscous, amber colored with a WBC 200-2000/mL and a predominance of mononuclear cell.
  3. Inflammatory fluid is turbid, yellow, with an increased WBC count 2,000 to 50,000/mL and a polymorphonuclear leukocytic predominance.

3a. Inflammatory fluid has reduced viscosity, diminished hyaluronate.

3b. Infections (pyogenic) is purulent, WBC count > 50,000/ mL, PMN > 90%

3c. Infections (Tuberculosis/granulomatous) is yellow, turbid, WBC count 10,000–20,000/mL, PMN 60% and presence of lymphocytes, plasma cells and histiocytes.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Acute pyogenic arthritis. Acute pyogenic arthritis is caused by a bacterial infection in the joint, and the synovial fluid in this condition typically shows an increased number of neutrophils (polymorphonuclear leukocytes).

 

Option B. Chronic arthritis. Chronic arthritis is a broad term that can encompass various chronic inflammatory joint conditions like osteoarthritis.

 

Option D. Rheumatoid arthritis. Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic autoimmune inflammatory arthritis characterized by the presence of synovitis. The synovial fluid contains > 50% neutrophils, 5000-50,000 cells, T-lymphocytes, plasma cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In synovial fluid of patients with granulomatous arthritis, numerous lymphocytes, plasma cells and histiocytes are found.

questions.text: In Articular cartilage, most active chondrocytes are seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Zone 3

 

Option C)

 

CHONDROCYTES

 

  • The chondrocytes are arranged in columns perpendicular to the articular surface.
  • They undergo active cell division/proliferation to produce new matrix components like collagen and proteoglycans. 
  • Chondrocytes in this zone are involved in collagen synthesis to anchor the cartilage to the subchondral bone.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Zone 1. The chondrocytes in this zone are flat and oriented parallel to the articular surface. These cells in this zone are involved in lubrication and reducing friction within the joint.

 

Option B. Zone 2. The chondrocytes in this zone are arranged in columns or clusters. They play a crucial role in growth and maintenance of the cartilage tissue.

 

Option D. Zone 4. The chondrocytes in this zone are embedded within the calcified cartilage. This zone is the transition between cartilage and bone, with chondrocytes undergoing apoptosis as the cartilage mineralizes and becomes ossified.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Articular cartilage, Chondrocytes are more active synthetically in middle zone or radial zone or deep zone (zone 3).

choices.text: Secreted primarily by type A synovial cells
Follows Non-Newtonian fluid kinetics
Contains hyaluronic acid
Viscosity is variable

questions.text: All of the following statements about synovial fluid are true, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Secreted primarily by type A synovial cells

 

Option A)

 

  • Synovial fluid is secreted by type B synovial cells (type B synoviocytes).

 

SYNOVIAL FLUID

 

  • Synovial Fluid is an ultra-dialysate of blood plasma transudated from synovial capillaries to which hyaluronic acid protein complex (mucin) has been added by synovial B cells.
  • Type A synovial cells contains numerous mitochondria in cytoplasm. They are macrophage-like phagocytic cells, primarily concerned with phagocytosis of joint debris.
  • Type B synovial cells, which resemble fibroblasts and contain endoplasmic reticulum are secretion of hyaluronic acid, protein and prostaglandins of synovial fluid.
  • Fluid Kinetics of synovial fluid:
    • A Newtonian fluid is a fluid whose viscosity is constant in relation to rate of shear changes. Examples are All gasses and simple fluids.
    • In Non-Newtonian fluid, Viscosity changes with shear. It is of two types, Thixotropic and Rheotropic.
    • Thixotropic fluids:
      • Fluids whose viscosity decreases with increased rates of shear, e.g. Synovial fluid.
      • Viscosity of synovial fluid is primarily because of the high levels of hyaluronate.
    • Rheotropic fluids:
      • Fluids whose viscosity increases with increased rates of shear, e.g. printer ink

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Follows Non-Newtonian fluid kinetics. True. Synovial fluid exhibits non-Newtonian behaviour, i.e., its viscosity changes with the rate of shear applied. This property allows the fluid to become less viscous during joint movement, facilitating smooth articulation.

 

Option C. Contains hyaluronic acid. True. Synovial fluid contains hyaluronic acid, a glycosaminoglycan that contributes to the lubrication and viscosity of the fluid. Hyaluronic acid helps in maintaining the integrity of the synovial fluid film on joint surfaces.

 

Option D. Viscosity is variable. True. The viscosity of synovial fluid is variable and influenced by factors such as hydration, the presence of hyaluronic acid, and the overall health of the joint. Viscosity tends to increase with rest and decrease with joint movement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Synovial fluid follows Non-Newtonian fluid kinetics.
  • It contains hyaluronic acid.
  • Its viscosity is variable.
  • It is an ultra-dialysate of blood plasma transudated from synovial capillaries to which hyaluronic acid protein complex (mucin) has been added by synovial B cells.

choices.text: Total proteoglycan content is decreased
Synthesis of proteoglycans is decreased
Enzymatic degradation of proteoglycans is increased
Total water content of cartilage is decrease

questions.text: Which of the following statements about changes in articular cartilage with aging is not true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Enzymatic degradation of proteoglycans is increased

 

Option C)

 

CHANGES IN ARTICULAR CARTILAGE WITH AGING

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Total proteoglycan content is decreased. True. Proteoglycans are the molecules in the extracellular fluid that help maintain its structure and function. With ageing, the total proteolytic enzyme degradation decreases with increasing age.

 

Option B. Synthesis of proteoglycans is decreased. True. With aging, there is a decrease in the synthesis of proteoglycans by chondrocytes. This reduction in synthesis contributes to the decline in total proteoglycan content observed in aging cartilage.

 

Option D. Total water content of cartilage is decreased. True. With aging, the total water content of the cartilage is decreased. In osteoarthritis, it is increased, but decreased in advanced OA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Enzymatic degradation of proteoglycans is normal with ageing.
  • Total proteoglycan content is decreased.
  • Synthesis of proteoglycans is decreased.
  • Total water content of cartilage is decreased.

choices.text: Complete loss of sensation at joint position at resting stage
Loss of sensation of joint position at dynamic stage
All types of sensation lost

questions.text: After knee replacement surgery, proprioceptors of joints are altered. Effect is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Normal movement

 

Option A)

 

KNEE REPLACEMENT SURGERY

 

  • Joint proprioception and kinesthesia improve after total knee arthroplasty.
  • Joint sensation is decreased in arthritic knee but improves after knee arthroplasty when compared with that of contralateral limb because following total knee arthroplasty, the joint space and soft tissue tension are re-established.
  • These changes may modify the response characteristics of mechanoreceptors in both capsuloligamentous and musculotendinous structures, enhancing the perception of joint motion and position.
  • The movement improves after replacement or remains at least is the same as preoperative range.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Complete loss of sensation at joint position at resting stage. Complete loss of sensation at the joint position, particularly at the resting stage could result in challenges for the patient in maintaining a sense of joint position when the knee is at rest.

 

Option C. Loss of sensation of joints position at dynamic stage. This suggests that the alteration in proprioception is more prominent during dynamic movements rather than at rest. 

 

Option D. All types of sensation lost. This implies a complete loss of sensation, which would include not only proprioception but also other types of sensory feedback.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • After knee replacement surgery, proprioceptors of joints are altered and the effect will occur on Normal movements. Normal movement may be retained.

questions.text: Metal on metal articulation should be avoided in:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Young female

 

Option B)

 

METAL ON METAL ARTICULATION

 

  • Metal on metal articulation consist of a metal ball that articulates with a metal socket.
  • It should be avoided in young females because of its association with high failure rates and complications like:
    • Metal ion release
    • Hypersensitivity
    • Higher physical demands

 

 

 

  • Contraindications of Metal on Metal Bearing Surfaces:
    • Patients with Renal Insufficiency because kidneys are chiefly responsible for eliminating metal ions from the blood.
    • Young females of child-bearing age, as metal ions may cross the placenta and damage the fetus
    • Patients with metal hypersensitivity.
    • They can also cause chromosomal changes.
    • Their role in carcinogenesis is under evaluation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Osteonecrosis. Osteonecrosis is the death of bone tissue due to a lack of blood supply. Metal-on-metal articulation is not specifically contraindicated in osteonecrosis.

 

Option C. Inflammatory arthritis. Metal-on-metal articulation is generally not recommended in patients with inflammatory arthritis, such as rheumatoid arthritis. Inflammatory arthritis patients may have an increased risk of adverse reactions to metal debris, making alternative implant materials, like ceramic or polyethylene, more suitable.

 

Option D. Revision surgery. Metal-on-metal articulation is sometimes used in revision surgery, but its use has declined due to concerns about metal ion release. In revision surgeries, the choice of implant material depends on various factors, including the reason for revision and the condition of the surrounding bone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Metal-on-metal articulation is often avoided in young, active females due to concerns about wear and the potential for metal ion release.
  • This patient population may have a longer life expectancy, and concerns about the long-term effects of metal ions make alternative implant materials more favourable.
  • They are also avoided in females in a child bearing age as the metal ions can cross the placenta, causing damage to the fetus.

questions.text: A patient developed breathlessness and chest pain on second postoperative after a total hip replacement. Echocardiography showed right ventricular dilatation and tricuspid regurgitation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pulmonary embolism

 

Option B)
