  • Chest pain and breathlessness, together with echocardiographic evidence of right ventricular dilatation and tricuspid regurgitation after a high-risk procedure (for thromboembolism) like total hip replacement suggests a diagnosis of pulmonary embolism.
  • Thromboembolic disease (TED) is one of the most common serious complication of THR.
  • The 30-day mortality rate from pulmonary embolism in patients undergoing elective THR was 0.04%, behind myocardial infarction (MI) and cardiorespiratory arrest.
  • Pulmonary thromboembolism is characterized by obstruction of main pulmonary artery or its branches by a thrombus which was originated elsewhere.
  • It results in V/Q mismatch due to sufficient ventilation but no perfusion.
  • Clinically, the patient presents with pleuritic chest pain, dyspnea which increases on exertion, tachypnea, tachycardia.
  • Screening is done by evaluating the D-dimer levels.
  • IOC: CECT Chest or CTPA
  • ECG shows sinus tachycardia (most common), S1Q3T3 (most specific)
  • Echocardiography shows McConell Sign (RV hypokinesia, hyperkinetic apex)
  • Chest X-ray shows Hampton Hump sign (wedge-shaped opacity), Palla sign (prominent right

descending pulmonary artery), Westermark sign (increased lucency due to focal oligemia).

  • Treatment – Anticoagulation therapy (Heparin, direct thrombin/Factor Xa inhibitors).
  • If Anticoagulation is contraindicated, IVC filter may be used.
  • If patient is unstable, perform systemic thrombolysis.
  • If thrombolysis is C/I, Mechanical embolectomy should be done.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Acute MI. Acute MI refers to the sudden death of part of the heart muscle due to a lack of blood supply. Symptoms include chest pain, shortness of breath, and can sometimes lead to complications such as heart failure with right ventricular dilatation and tricuspid regurgitation, is more indicative of a condition affecting the pulmonary circulation rather than a primary cardiac event. Myocardial infarction can occur after hip replacement surgery but it is less commonly seen than pulmonary thromboembolism.

 

Option C. Hypotensive shock. Hypotensive shock refers to a state of insufficient blood flow to meet the body's needs, resulting in low blood pressure. While it can cause symptoms like breathlessness, it usually doesn't present with right ventricular dilatation and tricuspid regurgitation on echocardiography. Total knee arthroplasty can cause severe blood loss that can lead to hypovolemic shock.

 

Option D. Cardiac Tamponade. Cardiac tamponade is a condition where fluid accumulates in the pericardial sac, compressing the heart. This can lead to symptoms such as chest pain and shortness of breath. However, it typically presents with other signs, and echocardiography in cardiac tamponade may reveal features like diastolic collapse of the right atrium and right ventricle, rather than right ventricular dilatation and tricuspid regurgitation. This condition is rarely seen, but can be seen after posterior pedicle screw fixation of the spine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pulmonary embolism occurs when a blood clot, usually originating from the legs (deep vein thrombosis), travels to the lungs and blocks a pulmonary artery.
  • Symptoms can include sudden onset of breathlessness, chest pain, and in severe cases, right heart strain as evidenced by right ventricular dilatation and tricuspid regurgitation on echocardiography.
  • This is seen as a common complication of total hip replacement surgeries.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of death after total hip replacement?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pulmonary embolism

 

Option C)

 

  • Cause of mortality after joint replacement order is myocardial Infarction > cardiorespiratory arrest > thromboembolism.
  • Thromboembolic disease (TED) is one of the most common serious complication following joint replacement surgeries.
  • The 30-day mortality rate from pulmonary embolism in patients undergoing elective THR is 0.04%, behind myocardial infarction (MI) and cardiorespiratory arrest.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Infections. Infection is a potential complication after total hip replacement, but it is not typically the most common cause of death. Infections can lead to local complications, such as joint infections (septic arthritis), which may require surgical intervention. Systemic spread leading to death is less common.

 

Option B. Deep Vein Thrombosis. It is a significant concern after total hip replacement due to the risk of blood clots forming in the deep veins, usually in the legs. While Deep Vein Thrombosis itself is a serious condition, the most life-threatening complication arises when a clot breaks loose and travels to the lungs, causing a pulmonary embolism (PE).

 

Option D. Pneumonia. Pneumonia, an infection of the lungs, can occur after surgery due to factors such as immobility, anesthesia, and decreased lung function. While pneumonia is a concern, it is generally less common as the primary cause of death after total hip replacement compared to complications like pulmonary embolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pulmonary embolism occurs when a blood clot, often originating from the deep veins of the legs, travels to the lungs, causing a blockage in the pulmonary arteries.
  • This can be a severe and life-threatening complication, especially after orthopedic surgeries where immobility and surgical trauma contribute to the risk of clot formation.

choices.text: High density polyethylene debris

questions.text: Aseptic loosening in cemented total hip replacement occurs as a result of hypersensitivity response to:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) High density polyethylene debris

 

Option B)

 

ASEPTIC LOOSENING IN CEMENTED THR

 

  • Aseptic loosening in cemented total hip replacement occurs when the artificial hip components become loose from the bone without any infection present.
  • This is typically due to a combination of mechanical factors and biological responses.
  • Particles of metal (titanium, nickel, chromium, etc.), cement (PMMA) and polyethylene can produce periprosthetic osteolysis (aseptic loosening).
  • Polyethylene particles appear to be the major particles causing the damage.
  • High density polyethylene (HDPE) is often used in the acetabular component of hip implants.
  • Over time, wear and friction can lead to the generation of small particles of HDPE debris.
  • These particles can trigger an inflammatory response in the surrounding tissues, leading to bone loss and ultimately aseptic loosening of the implant.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Titanium debris. Titanium is a biocompatible material commonly used in orthopedic implants. While titanium debris can be generated from the wear and tear of the implant, it is not typically associated with aseptic loosening. Titanium is generally well-tolerated by the body, and adverse reactions to titanium debris are uncommon.

 

Option C. N, N-Dimethyltryptamine. N, N-Dimethyltryptamine (DMT) is a naturally occurring psychedelic compound, and it is not relevant to hip replacement or aseptic loosening. It is not used in implant materials, and there is no association between DMT and hip replacement complications.

 

Option D. Free Radicals.  Free radicals are reactive molecules that can contribute to oxidative stress and tissue damage. While oxidative stress can play a role in the inflammatory response to wear debris, the direct association of free radicals as a cause of aseptic loosening is not as specific as the association with the wear debris itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Particles of metal (titanium, nickel, chromium, etc.), cement (PMMA) and polyethylene all can produce periprosthetic osteolysis (aseptic loosening).
  • Polyethylene particles appear to be the major particles causing the damage.
  • Since high density polyethylene is used in the acetabular component of the implant, its wearing out and friction generates small particles that can cause inflammatory response in tissues, leading to loosening of the implant.

questions.text:
Major indication(s) for arthroplasty are:

 

  1. Osteoarthritis of hip
  2. Ankylosis of elbow
  3. Un-united tibial fracture
  4. Un-united femoral neck fracture
  5. TB spine
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 4

 

Option C)

 

ARTHROPLASTY

 

  • Arthroplasty means construction of a new movable joint.
  • Arthroplasty can be done for any disease any joint except active infection.
  • Important conditions for which arthroplasty is indicated are:
    • severe osteoarthritis of the hip and knee joints
    • advanced rheumatoid arthritis with disabling pain
    • quiescent destructive tuberculous arthritis
    • non-united femoral neck fracture
    • correction of deformities like hallux valgus
    • avascular necrosis
  • Types of arthroplasty:
  1. Excision arthroplasty: It is done for Hip and Elbow. It is characterized by excision of one or both articular ends creating a gap that is later filled by the fibrous tissue itself.
  2. Hemiarthroplasty or half joint replacement: It is done for fracture of neck of femur in elderly patients. In this, one of the articular surface is replaced with a similar metallic prosthesis (e.g. Austin Moore).
  3. Total replacement arthroplasty: It is done for Osteoarthritis of Hip. In this, Both the ends of articular surfaces are excised and replaced with prosthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Arthroplasty means construction of a new movable joint.
  • Indications of arthroplasty is osteoarthritis of the hip and knee, ankyloses of the elbow, un-united femoral neck fracture.

choices.text: Osteoarthritis of the distal interphalangeal joints
Osteoarthritis of the proximal interphalangeal joints
Osteoarthritis of the proximal interphalangeal joints
Rheumatoid arthritis of the 1st carpometacarpal joint

questions.text: Heberden's nodes are seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Osteoarthritis of the distal interphalangeal joints

 

Option A)

 

HEBERDEN’S NODES

 

  • Localized (Monoarticular and Pauci-articular) OA involves:

 

 

  • DIP joint OA presents as Heberden’s node while that of PIP joint presents as Bouchard’s node.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Osteoarthritis of the proximal interphalangeal joints. Osteoarthritis of the PIP joint of the hand presents as Bouchard’s nodes.

 

Option C. Rheumatoid arthritis of the 1st carpometacarpal joint. Rheumatoid arthritis of the 1st CMC joint of the hand i.e. the base of the thumb presents as the swan neck deformity of the thumb. This involves hyperextension of the interphalangeal joint and flexion of the MCP joint with a consequent loss of thumb mobility and pinch.

 

Option D. Rheumatoid arthritis of the distal interphalangeal joints. RA of the DIP joint may present as swan neck deformity i.e., hyperextension of PIP joint and compensatory flexion of the DIP joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Heberden's nodes are a classic feature of osteoarthritis, particularly affecting the DIP joints.

choices.text: Osteoarthritis of the distal interphalangeal joints
Osteoarthritis of the proximal interphalangeal joints
Rheumatoid arthritis of the 1st carpometacarpal joint
Rheumatoid arthritis of the distal interphalangeal joints

questions.text: Bouchard's nodes are seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteoarthritis of the proximal interphalangeal joints

 

Option B)

 

BOUCHARD’S NODES

 

  • PIP joint of the hand, when involved in osteoarthritis, presents as Bouchard’s node.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Osteoarthritis of the distal interphalangeal joints Heberden's nodes are associated with OA at the DIP joints, not the PIP joints.

 

Option C. Rheumatoid arthritis of the 1st carpometacarpal joint. Rheumatoid arthritis of the 1st CMC joint of the hand i.e. the base of the thumb presents as the swan neck deformity of the thumb. This involves hyperextension of the interphalangeal joint and flexion of the MCP joint with a consequent loss of thumb mobility and pinch.

 

Option D. Rheumatoid arthritis of the distal interphalangeal joints. RA of the DIP joint may present as swan neck deformity i.e., hyperextension of PIP joint and compensatory flexion of the DIP joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bouchard's nodes are associated with osteoarthritis, particularly affecting the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints.
  • The characteristic bony enlargements or osteophytes at the PIP joints are a hallmark feature of osteoarthritis.

questions.text: Which one of the following bursae always communicates with knee joint cavity?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Suprapatellar

 

Option B)

 

BURSAE OF KNEE

 

  • Four bursa communicate with synovial cavity of knee joint:
  1. Suprapatellar bursa
  2. Popliteus bursa (deep to distal quadriceps)
  3. Anserine bursa (deep to tendinous attachments of sartorius, gracilis and semi-tendinous)
  4. Gastrocnemius bursa

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Prepatellar. It is situated in front of the patella, between the skin and the patellar ligament. It reduces friction between the skin and the patella during knee movement. It does not communicate directly with the knee joint cavity. It is a separate bursa.

 

Option C. Superficial infrapatellar. Found just below the skin and above the patellar ligament, it aids in reducing friction between the skin and the patellar ligament. It does not directly communicate with the knee joint cavity.

 

Option D. Deep infrapatellar. Situated deep within the knee joint, beneath the patellar ligament, it helps to protect the joint and absorb shocks during movements. It does not directly communicate with the knee joint cavity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Located above the patella, between the quadriceps tendon and the femur, suprapatellar bursa helps in reducing friction between the quadriceps tendon and the distal femur during knee movements.
  • It communicates with the knee joint cavity.
  • An opening called the "suprapatellar pouch" extends into the joint.

questions.text: A 60 years old female has a previous case history of fever, fatigue, weight loss and polyarthralgia. She had morning stiffness and bilateral hand pain. The radiological findings are given below. What may be your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rheumatoid arthritis

 

Option B)

 

RHEUMATOID ARTHRITIS

 

  • Based on the clinical presentation and the radiological findings described, the most likely diagnosis for the 60-year-old female is Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA).
  • Rheumatoid arthritis often presents with systemic symptoms like fever, fatigue, and weight loss, along with multiple joint pain (polyarthralgia).
  • Morning stiffness lasting for more than 30 minutes, particularly in the small joints of the hands and wrists, is a classic feature of rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Bilateral hand pain further supports this.
  • The radiological findings typically show erosions and joint space narrowing, particularly in the small joints of the hands and wrists.
  • The x-ray shows deformities in the hand that are characteristic of rheumatoid arthritis.
  • X-rays also reveal periarticular osteopenia, which is another feature of RA.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Osteoarthritis. Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease characterized by the breakdown of joint cartilage and the underlying bone. X-ray findings in osteoarthritis include joint space narrowing, osteophyte formation, and subchondral sclerosis. Osteoarthritis is not associated with systemic symptoms like fever, fatigue, and weight loss.

 

Option C. Gout. Gout is an inflammatory arthritis caused by the deposition of urate crystals in joints, leading to sudden attacks of pain and swelling. In chronic gout, X-ray may show joint erosions and the presence of tophi (deposits of urate crystals). Gout typically presents as acute, intermittent attacks rather than chronic, progressive joint involvement.

 

Option D. Psoriatic Arthritis. Psoriatic arthritis is an inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis. May include joint erosions and new bone formation (ankylosis). Psoriatic arthritis often involves the axial skeleton and may have distinct radiological features compared to RA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The combination of symptoms like fever, weight loss, fatigue and the involvement of multiple joints, including the hands, is consistent with rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
  • Radiological findings, such as joint erosions and periarticular osteopenia, are commonly associated with RA.

choices.text: Osteophytes are seen in osteoarthritis
Systemic symptoms are seen in osteoarthritis
Rheumatoid arthritis is uncommon in hands and feet
Osteoarthritis is an autoimmune disease

questions.text: Which of the following is the difference between Rheumatoid arthritis and osteoarthritis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Osteophytes are seen in osteoarthritis

 

Option A)

 

DIFFERENCE BETWEEN OSTEOARTHRITIS AND RHEUMATOID ARTHRITIS

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Osteophytes are seen in osteoarthritis. True. Osteoarthritis is characterized by the presence of osteophytes which are the osteocartilaginous outgrowth at the joint margins where the synovium attaches to the edge of the articular cartilage and merges with the periosteum.

 

Option B. Systemic symptoms are seen in osteoarthritis. False. Systemic symptoms such as fever, fatigue are seen in rheumatoid arthritis and are not associated with osteoarthritis.

 

Option C. Rheumatoid arthritis is uncommon in hands and feet. False. Rheumatoid arthritis often affects small joints, including those in the hands and feet. Osteoarthritis is more commonly seen in the large joints like the knees and the hips.

 

Option D. Osteoarthritis is an autoimmune disease. False. Osteoarthritis is not considered as an autoimmune disease. It is an age-related, mechanical, degenerative disease of the joints.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Osteophytes, also known as bone spurs, are commonly seen in osteoarthritis. They form at the joint margins as a result of the degeneration of cartilage and are a characteristic feature of OA and not RA.

questions.text: Most specific antibody seen in RA is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anti CCP

 

Option A)

 

ANTIBODY IN RA

 

  • Anti-CCP antibodies or anti-Citrullinated cyclic peptide antibodies are positive in up to 98% of patient.
  • 2% of general population has anti-CCP positive.
  • It is most specific marker for RA.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Rheumatoid factor. Rheumatoid factor is an antibody directed against the Fc portion of immunoglobulin G (IgG). It can be positive in a subset of RA patients, but its sensitivity and specificity are lower compared to anti-CCP antibodies.

 

Option C. ANA (Antinuclear Antibodies). Antinuclear antibodies target components of the cell nucleus. While ANA can be positive in a variety of autoimmune conditions, it is not specific to RA.

 

Option D. Anti dsDNA antibodies. Anti-dsDNA antibodies target double-stranded DNA. Elevated levels of anti-dsDNA antibodies are often seen in SLE and are part of the criteria for diagnosing lupus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The anti-CCP, rheumatoid factor, ANA have a high specificity for RA, and their presence is often considered an important diagnostic marker, especially in the early stages of the disease.
  • Out of the given options, Anti-CCP antibodies are the most specific marker for RA diagnosis.

questions.text:
A person has injury on dorsal surface of proximal interphalangeal joint of right middle finger. Which of the following can occur? 

 

  1. Rupture of lateral ligament
  2. Buttonhole deformity 
  3. Mallet finger
  4. Laceration of the central slip of the extensor
  5. Swan Neck deformity
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Only 2 & 4

 

Option C)

 

  • The injury describedon the dorsal surface of the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint of the right middle fingersuggests potential damage to the extensor mechanism of the finger. 

 

 

  • Buttonhole or Boutonniere deformity occurs due to a central slip injury to the extensor tendon, leading to the inability to extend the PIP joint while the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint stays hyperextended. A dorsal injury at the PIP joint can cause this. 
  • The central slip of the extensor tendon is pulled through the PIP joint, leading to an abnormal flexion posture of the joint.

 

 

Boutonniere deformity 

 

  • Laceration of the central slip of the extensor can occur with a dorsal injury to the PIP joint, leading to Boutonniere deformity. Hence, this is possible.

 

Other Options:

 

1. Rupture of lateral ligament: The lateral or collateral ligament is more commonly associated with the radial and ulnar sides of the PIP joint rather than the dorsal surface. Severe injury to the PIP joint like dislocation can involve rupture of these ligaments. An isolated dorsal injury is less likely to cause a rupture of this ligament.

 

3. Mallet finger: This occurs due to a rupture of the extensor tendon at the DIP joint, not at the PIP joint. Therefore, a dorsal PIP injury would not cause a mallet finger.

 

 

5. Swan Neck deformity: This results from a hyperextension injury of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint. It is less likely to occur directly from a dorsal injury at the PIP joint. While it can be caused by various factors, including untreated mallet finger or rheumatoid arthritis, it is more commonly associated with conditions that lead to volar plate laxity or imbalance of the extensor mechanism, rather than a direct dorsal injury to the central slip that causes flexion.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Both the Buttonhole deformity and laceration of the central slip can occur due to the described injury on the PIP joint. 
  • Rupture of lateral ligament can be possible, but is not the only one. 
  • Swan Neck deformity is unlikely as a primary result of this specific injury type. 
  • Laceration of the central slip causes a boutonnire deformity. They are two sides of the same coin in this context. 
  • The central slip of the extensor tendon is located on the dorsal surface of the PIP joint. Therefore, injury to this slip (laceration) leads to the characteristic boutonnire deformity.

choices.text: Spine lateral view flexion and extension views
Open mouth view

questions.text: A middle aged female with rheumatoid arthritis on treatment develops upper motor neuron signs in her limbs. The investigation required to evaluate her further is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Spine lateral view flexion and extension views

 

Option A)

 

ATLANTOAXIAL INSTABILITY

 

  • Atlantoaxial instability (AAI) is characterized by excessive movement at the junction between the atlas (C1) and axis (C2) as a result of either a bony or ligamentous abnormality.
  • Neurologic symptoms occur when the spinal cord is involved and shows upper motor neuron signs in limbs.
  • The causes of AAI are varied.
  • AAI sometimes results from trauma.
  • Other causes occur secondary to an upper respiratory infection or infection following head and neck surgery.
  • Another cause is rheumatoid arthritis (RA), with its predilection for the upper cervical spine.
  • In addition, congenital anomalies, syndromes, or metabolic diseases can increase the risk of AAI.
  • The assessment involves flexion-extension lateral view of cervical spine that can assess this instability.

 

 

Flexion and extension of spine to show instability

 

  • Open mouth view is for atlantoaxial area especially dens, but will not demonstrate instability.
  • Swimmer’s view is for cervicothoracic junction assessment.
  • Broden’s view is for subtalar joint.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Open mouth view. The open mouth view, also known as the odontoid view. Open mouth view is for atlantoaxial area specially dens but it does not demonstrate instability.

 

 

 

Option C. Swimmer’s View. The swimmer's view is another radiographic projection that visualizes the cervicothoracic junction, particularly the lower cervical spine and upper thoracic spine.

 

 

Option C. Broden’s View. Broden's view is a specialized radiographic view that is obtained with the patient in the supine position, designed to assess atlantoaxial stability. Broden’s view is for subtalar joint.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The presence of upper motor neuron signs in the limbs in a patient diagnosed with RA suggests the presence of atlantoaxial joint instability.
  • The assessment for the same involves flexion-extension lateral view of cervical spine.
  • Other views like open mouth and swimmer’s views do not provide the clear image of this instability while the Broden’s view is used for the assessment of the subtalar joint of the foot.

choices.text: Typically involves small and large joints symmetrically but spares the cervical spine
Causes pleural effusion with low sugar
Pulmonary nodules are absent

questions.text: Which of the following is TRUE regarding Rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Causes pleural effusion with low sugar

 

Option B)

 

RHEUMATOID ARTHRITIS

 

  • RA causes pleural effusion with low glucose and pH.
  • RA affects the pleura in up to 5% of cases and, in keeping with other extraarticular manifestations of the disease, is more common in men.
  • Rheumatoid effusions characteristically have a low glucose and pH.
  • If the pleural fluid glucose is >28.8 mg/dl, rheumatoid is an unlikely cause. 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Typically involves small and large joints symmetrically but spares the cervical spine. Rheumatoid arthritis typically involves small and large joints symmetrically but in the spine, the upper cervical spine is most commonly affected. The lumbar spine is usually spared in RA.

 

Option C. Pulmonary nodules are absent. Rheumatoid arthritis can have pulmonary manifestations, and pulmonary nodules are one of them. Pulmonary nodules in RA can be seen on chest imaging, and they are considered a known complication.

 

Option D. Enthesopathy prominent. Enthesopathy (inflammation at sites of tendon or ligament attachments) is not a prominent feature of RA. Enthesopathy is more commonly associated with spondyloarthropathies rather than RA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • RA causes pleural effusion with low glucose and pH.
  • Enthesopathy is not seen in RA, it is a feature of Ankylosing Spondylitis.
  • Most common part of spine affected in RA is upper cervical.

questions.text: “Wind-swept deformity” is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rickets

 

Option D)

 

WIND SWEPT DEFORMITY

 

  • Wind swept deformity – Rickets > Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Wind swept deformity is classically used for knee deformity of rickets.
  • Windswept deformity:
  1. Knee: A valgus deformity of one knee in association of varus deformity of other knee is known as windswept deformity of the knees. It is seen in rickets, hereditary dysplasia (epiphyseal dysplasia) of bone and rheumatoid arthritis.

 

 

  1. Foot: Deviation of all toes in one direction (usually laterally) is known as windswept deformity of the toes. It is seen in rheumatoid arthritis.

 

 

  1. Hand: Deviation of all fingers (usually medially) is known as windswept deformity of the fingers. It is seen in rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ankylosing Spondylitis. Ankylosing spondylitis primarily affects the spine and sacroiliac joints. Ankylosing spondylitis can lead to spinal deformities like kyphosis and lack of spinal mobility.

 

Option B. Scurvy. Scurvy is a nutritional deficiency disorder caused by vitamin C deficiency. Wind-swept deformity is not associated with scurvy.

 

Option C. Rheumatoid Arthritis. Rheumatoid arthritis primarily affects the joints, including the spine. Wind-swept deformity is not a classic term associated with rheumatoid arthritis. It is seen in RA but is more common in rickets.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rickets is a condition caused by vitamin D deficiency, leading to impaired bone mineralization.
  • Wind-swept deformity is associated with rickets, specifically a deformity in which the lower limbs are bowed outward while the upper limbs are bowed inward.

questions.text: A young male having pain with daily morning stiffness of spine for 30 minutes and reduced chest movements. Most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ankylosing spondylitis

 

Option A)

 

ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS

 

  • The symptoms described of morning stiffness in the spine lasting for 30 minutes and reduced chest movements are classic features of a condition called ankylosing spondylitis (AS).
  • Ankylosing spondylitis typically presents with morning stiffness that improves with activity.
  • This stiffness often lasts for at least 30 minutes or more and can be a prominent feature of the condition.
  • Ankylosing spondylitis can lead to inflammation and fusion of the spinal vertebrae, including those in the thoracic region.
  • As the disease progresses, the spine becomes less flexible, affecting chest movements.
  • This can result in reduced chest expansion and potentially lead to restrictive lung disease.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Rheumatoid arthritis. RA is a systemic autoimmune disease that primarily affects peripheral joints. Morning stiffness is common in RA but typically lasts for a shorter duration compared to AS. While RA can affect the cervical spine, it is not the primary site of involvement, and chest movements are not typically significantly reduced.

 

Option C. Gouty Arthritis. Gout primarily affects peripheral joints and is characterized by recurrent attacks of inflammatory arthritis. Morning stiffness is less characteristic of gout, and spine involvement is not a typical feature.

 

Option D. Osteoarthritis. OA is a degenerative joint disease that commonly affects weight-bearing joints. Morning stiffness in OA is usually brief and improves with movement. While OA can affect the spine, the described pattern of morning stiffness and reduced chest movements is not typical for OA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ankylosing spondylitis is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy characterized by inflammatory back pain, morning stiffness lasting more than 30 minutes, and reduced chest movements due to involvement of the spine and costovertebral joints.

questions.text: A young man complaints of pain in lower back. His X-rays are shown below. Most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ankylosing Spondylitis

 

Option A)

 

ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS

 

  • The given x-ray images of the patient shows bamboo spine and dagger sign in the spine which are characteristic of ankylosing spondylitis.
  • Bamboo spine occurs as a result of vertebral body fusion by marginal syndesmophytes.
  • In a bamboo spine, the outer fibres of the annulus fibrosus of the intervertebral discs ossify, which results in the formation of marginal syndesmophytes between adjoining vertebral bodies.
  • The resulting radiographic appearance, therefore, is that of thin, curved, radiopaque spicules that completely bridge adjoining vertebral bodies.
  • There is also accompanying squaring of the anterior vertebral body margins with associated reactive sclerosis of the vertebral body margins.
  • Together these give the impression of undulating continuous lateral spinal borders on AP spinal radiographs and resemble a bamboo stem; hence the term bamboo spine.

 

 

  • Dagger sign is the single central radiodense line on frontal radiographs related to ossification along supraspinous and interspinous ligaments secondary to enthesitis.
  • Dagger is a thin knife, the ossification resembles it, thus the term Dagger sign.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Spondylolisthesis. Spondylolisthesis is a condition where one vertebra slips forward over the vertebra below it. On X-ray, spondylolisthesis may appear as a forward displacement of one vertebra over another, and it is often associated with specific changes like "step-off" or "spondylolytic defects."

 

 

 

Option C. Paget’s disease. Paget's disease of bone is a chronic disorder that results in enlarged and misshapen bones. X-rays of the spine may show areas of increased bone density, presenting as ivory vertebra.

 

 

Option D. Osteoporosis. Osteoporosis is a condition characterized by weakened bones with an increased risk of fractures. Osteoporosis in the spinal x-ray can be seen as fish mouth vertebra.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • According to the x-ray provided in the question, the patient is diagnosed with ankylosing spondylitis.
  • It is chronic inflammatory condition that primarily affects the spine and sacroiliac joints.
  • It often presents as bamboo spine and dagger sign on X-rays as shown in the question.

questions.text: Resorption of distal phalanx is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All

 

Option D)

 

RESORPTION OF THE TUFT

 

  • Acro-osteolysis, also known as phalangeal osteolysis, refers to resorption of the distal phalanx.
  • The terminal tuft or distal phalanx is most commonly affected.
  • It is associated with a heterogeneous group of pathological entities like scleroderma, hyperparathyroidism, Reiter’s syndrome, etc.

 

 

  • Terminal tuft resorption occurs due to:
  1. Scleroderma
  2. Raynaud’s disease
  3. Psoriatic arthropathy: can precede the skin changes
  4. Neuropathic disease: diabetes mellitus, leprosy, myelomeningocele, syringomyelia and congenital indifference to pain
  5. Thermal injuries: burns, frostbite and electrical
  6. Trauma
  7. Hyperparathyroidism
  8. Epidermolysis bullosa
  9. Porphyria: due to cutaneous photosensitivity leading to blistering and scarring
  10. Phenytoin toxicity: congenitally in infants of epileptic mothers
  11. Subungual exostosis
  12. Snake and scorpion venom: due to tissue breakdown by proteinases

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

All of the provided options i.e., scleroderma, hyperparathyroidism and Reiter’s syndrome are associated with resorption of the distal phalanx or terminal tuft of the fingers.

choices.text: Cutaneous and mucosal lesions are rare
Enthesopathy is common
Associated with HLA B27
Hip is the commonest joint involved

questions.text: Which of the following is true about HIV-related arthritis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cutaneous and mucosal lesions are rare

 

Option A)

 

HIV-RELATED ARTHRITIS

 

  • Asymmetric oligoarthritis (MC)
  • Commonly seen in males.
  • Affects knees/ankles
  • Symmetrical polyarthritis
  • Non-erosive but otherwise mimics RA.
  • Enthesopathy & Mucocutaneous involvement is rare
  • Seronegative (RA factor -ve, ANA -ve, HLAB27 -ve).
  • NSAIDs as D.O.C.
  • HIV patients can develop seronegative arthropathy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Enthesopathy is common. False. Enthesopathy & Mucocutaneous involvement is rare in HIV-related arthritis.

 

Option C. Associated with HLA B27. False. Unlike other forms of arthritis like ankylosing spondylitis, HIV-related arthritis is not typically associated with HLA-B27. It is a seronegative arthropathy with RA factor, ANA and HLA B27 being negative.

 

Option D. Hip is the commonest joint involved. False. The joints commonly affected in HIV-related arthritis are typically large joints, with the knee being the most frequently involved, followed by the ankle joint.

                               

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cutaneous and mucosal lesions are rarely seen in HIV-related arthritis.
  • Enthesopathy is also rare.
  • It is not associated with HLA B27, RA factor or ANA.
  • Knee joint followed by ankle joint are the commonest joint involved.

choices.text: Subchondral bone cyst formation
Increase in intercondylar distance

questions.text: In Hemophiliac arthropathy, which of the following is not seen?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Juxta-articular osteosclerosis

 

Option C)

 

HEMOPHILIAC ARTHROPATHY

 

  • Hemophilia is an X-linked recessive disorder characterized by the absence or deficiency of factor VIII (hemophilia A or classical hemophilia) or factor IX (hemophilia B or Christmas disease).
  • Hemophilia A is more common accounting for ~85% cases.
  • Both disorders are manifested only in males but carried by females.
  • Recurrent spontaneous hemarthrosis causing chronic synovitis and progressive articular destruction occur in both.
  • Plasma clotting factor: 50% of the normal are compatible with normal control of hemorrhage.
  • Joints Bleeding:
    • Weight-bearing joints are most commonly involved, with the frequency of involvement in decreasing order, knee> elbow> shoulder> ankle> wrist> hip.
    • Ankle is most commonly involved in children.
    • Joint assumes position of minimal discomfort and minimal intra-articular pressure, which is, flexion (30–65), abduction (15) and lateral rotation (15) in hip; and slight flexion in knee.
    • Pain, warmth, boggy swelling, tenderness and limited movements cause it to resemble with low grade infection.
    • Joint aspiration is avoided unless distension is severe or there is a strong suspicion of infection.
  • Radiological Features:
    • Soft tissue swelling and capsular distension.
    • Juxta-articular osteopenia (not sclerosis).
    • Overgrowth and osteoporosis of epiphysis.
    • Marginal erosions and subchondral cysts.
    • Narrowing of joint space (with cartilage destruction) and bony over growth.
    • Widening of intercondylar notch of femur and squaring of distal end patella.
    • Enlargement of proximal radius and trochlear notch of ulna.
    • Total loss of joint space and fibrous ankylosis.

 

 

Explanation:

 

 Option A. Subchondral bone cyst formation. In hemophilic arthropathy, recurrent bleeding into the joints can lead to the formation of subchondral bone cysts. This occurs as a result of the breakdown of the joint structures and the presence of blood in the joint space, contributing to the destruction of the subchondral bone.

 

Option B. Increase in intercondylar distance. Widening of intercondylar notch of femur and squaring of distal end patella is seen in hemophilic arthropathy.

 

Option D. Subchondral thinning. Subchondral thinning refers to the reduction in thickness of the bone just beneath the joint cartilage. It is seen in Hemophiliac arthropathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Juxta- articular osteopenia and not osteosclerosis is seen in the radiographic of the hemophilic arthropathy.

choices.text: Chronic joint disease

questions.text: Arthroscopy is contraindicated in:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hemophilia

 

Option C)

 

ARTHROSCOPY

 

  • Arthroscopy is a minimally invasive surgical procedure used to diagnose and treat joint problems.
  • It involves inserting a small camera called an arthroscope into the joint through a small incision.
  • While arthroscopy can be beneficial for many joint conditions, it is contraindicated in hemophilic arthropathy due to the nature of hemophilia and its effects on the joints.
  • Hemophilic arthropathy is a complication of hemophilia, a genetic disorder that affects blood clotting.
  • In hemophilia, there is a deficiency in one of the blood clotting factors, typically factor VIII (hemophilia A) or factor IX (hemophilia B).
  • This deficiency leads to prolonged and spontaneous bleeding, especially into the joints.
  • Arthroscopy is contraindicated in hemophilic arthropathy because of risk of bleeding.
  • Individuals with hemophilia are at a high risk of bleeding.
  • Arthroscopy involves inserting instruments into the joint, which can cause damage to the joint tissues and potentially lead to bleeding.
  • Even minor bleeding can be difficult to control in hemophilic patients and can result in significant complications.
  • Due to this reasons, arthroscopy is generally avoided in individuals with hemophilic arthropathy.
  • Instead, conservative management approaches, such as physical therapy, pain management, and clotting factor replacement therapy, are often utilized to manage joint symptoms and prevent further joint damage.
  • If surgical intervention is necessary, alternative techniques that carry a lower risk of bleeding may be considered.
  • Treatment of acute hemarthrosis involves factor replacement (in hemophilia) joint aspiration (in severe cases), ice and analgesics (to relieve pain) rest and compressive bandage.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Chronic joint disease. Arthroscopy is generally performed to diagnose and treat various joint conditions. However, in advanced stages of chronic joint diseases, where there is significant joint destruction and deformity, arthroscopy may be effective.

 

Option B. Loose Bodies. Arthroscopy is commonly used to address loose bodies within a joint. Loose bodies are fragments of cartilage or bone that may interfere with joint movement and cause pain. Arthroscopy allows for the visualization and removal of these loose bodies, helping to improve joint function and alleviate symptoms.

 

Option D. Meniscal tear. Arthroscopy is often used to diagnose and treat meniscal tears. In this procedure, a surgeon can visualize the inside of the joint, identify the torn meniscus, and often repair or trim the damaged tissue. Arthroscopy is a common and effective method for managing meniscal tears.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Arthroscopy is generally a valuable tool for diagnosing and treating various joint conditions. 
  • It is contraindicated in individuals with hemophilia due to the increased risk of uncontrolled bleeding during the procedure.

questions.text: Charcot’s joint is another name for joint affected by:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neuropathy

 

Option A)

 

CHARCOT’S JOINT

 

It is progressive destructive arthritis arising from loss of pain sensation and proprioception (position sense).

So, lack normal reflex safe guards against abnormal stress or injury.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Osteoarthritis. Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease characterized by the breakdown of cartilage in the joints. It is a result of wear and tear on the joints over time. Charcot's joint is not associated with osteoarthritis.

 

Option C.  Rheumatoid arthritis. Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune disorder that primarily affects the synovium (lining of the joints), causing inflammation and joint damage. Charcot's joint is not typically associated with rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Option D. Ankylosing spondylitis. Ankylosing spondylitis is a type of inflammatory arthritis that primarily affects the spine. It is characterized by inflammation, fusion of joints, and eventual bone formation. Charcot's joint is not commonly associated with ankylosing spondylitis. Ankylosing spondylitis has distinct features, such as axial involvement and bamboo spine, which are different from the characteristics of Charcot's joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Charcot's joint is most commonly associated with neuropathy, especially in conditions such as diabetic neuropathy or neurosyphilis.
  • It is characterized by progressive degeneration, deformity, and instability of the affected joint due to impaired proprioception and sensory feedback caused by neuropathic conditions.

questions.text: Most common cause of neuropathic joints is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Diabetes

 

Option C)

 

NEUROPATHIC JOINT

 

  • The most common causes of neuropathic joints are:

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Leprosy. Leprosy, also known as Hansen's disease, can lead to neuropathic joint involvement. Leprosy affects peripheral nerves and can cause sensory and motor deficits. Neuropathic joints may develop in leprosy due to the loss of sensation and proprioception, leading to joint destruction and deformities.

 

Option B. Tabes dorsalis. Tabes dorsalis is a manifestation of tertiary syphilis that affects the dorsal columns of the spinal cord. It leads to sensory ataxia, impaired proprioception, and can result in Charcot joints. The loss of sensation and coordination contributes to the development of joint damage.

 

Option D. Nerve injury. Nerve injury, including traumatic injuries or surgical procedures that damage nerves, can contribute to the development of neuropathic joints. However, diabetes is more commonly associated with neuropathic joint than direct nerve injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • While various conditions can lead to neuropathic joint (Charcot joint), diabetes is recognized as the most common cause, primarily due to the widespread prevalence of diabetic neuropathy and its impact on sensory and motor function in peripheral nerves.

questions.text: A lady presents with right knee swelling, aspiration was done in which CPPD crystals were obtained. Next best investigation is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) TSH

 

Option D)

 

CPPD ARTHROPATHY

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. ANA. ANA testing is often used in the evaluation of autoimmune disorders, such as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) or other connective tissue diseases. However, it may not be the first-line investigation in the context of pseudogout, where CPPD crystals have already been identified.

 

Option B. RF. Rheumatoid factor (RF) is a blood test commonly used to help diagnose rheumatoid arthritis. This is not the investigation used in pseudogout. 

 

Option C. CPK. CPK is an enzyme that can be elevated in various conditions, including muscle damage. While CPK may be relevant in specific clinical scenarios, it is not a routine investigation for evaluating pseudogout.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Knee swelling and presence of CPPD crystals in aspirate are suggestive of presence of pseudogout in the patient.
  • Since pseudogout is associated with hypothyroidism most commonly, it is best advised to investigate for TSH levels in the patient.

questions.text: X-ray of a young man shows heterotopic calcification around bilateral knee joints. Next investigation would be:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Serum phosphate

 

Option A)

 

TUMORAL CALCINOSIS

 

  • Tumoral calcinosis is a rare condition which primarily, but not exclusively affects black people in otherwise good health.
  • This disease usually presents in the second decade of life and is characterized by deposition of painless calcific masses bilaterally around knee, hip, elbow or shoulder.
  • The primary defect responsible for this metastatic calcification appears to be hyperphosphatemia resulting from the increased capacity of renal tubule and intestines to absorb phosphate.
  • The most common laboratory findings are hyperphosphatemia and elevated serum 1,25-dihydroxy Vitamin-D levels.
  • Serum calcium, parathyroid hormone and alkaline phosphatase levels are usually normal.
  • Surgical excision is the most successful form of treatment if indicated although recurrences are common.
  • Medical treatment to control the hyperphosphatemia (e.g. a low phosphate diet and oral estimation of phosphate binders) is an important adjuvant to surgical excision.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Serum Calcium, Option C. Serum PTH, and Option D. Serum alkaline phosphatase are normal in level in tumoral calcinosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Heterotopic calcification refers to the abnormal deposition of calcium in soft tissues outside the skeletal system.
  • It can occur in various conditions, and assessing the serum levels of phosphate is important for the evaluation of metabolic and hormonal factors influencing calcium homeostasis.
  • The given complaint of presence of the calcification in bilateral knees is characteristic of tumor calcinosis.
  • In this rare condition, the serum calcium, PTH and ALP levels remains normal.
  • Since, hyperphosphatemia is the primary defect in this condition, it is important to investigate the serum phosphate levels to rule out the condition.

choices.text: Shoulder, elbow wrist involvement is characteristic
Elderly males are commonly involved
Endemic to northern Kwazulu Natal area in South Africa

questions.text: True statement regarding Mseleni joint disease is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Endemic to northern Kwazulu Natal area in South Africa

 

Option D)

 

MSELENI JOINT DISEASE

 

  • Epigenetic chondrodysplasia
  • This disease affects indigenous Bantu Population in Mseleni, Kwazulu Natal area, South Africa.
  • More common in females.
  • Hip is the commonest joint affected causing its arthritis.
  • The disease is often bilateral.
  • Severe short stature has been reported.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Shoulder, elbow wrist involvement is characteristic. This statement is incorrect. While Mseleni joint disease does involve joints, the specific involvement of shoulder, elbow, and wrist is not characteristic.

 

Option B. Elderly males are commonly involved. This statement is incorrect. Mseleni joint disease affects females more commonly than males.

 

Option C. Height is unaffected. This statement is not specific to Mseleni joint disease. The condition primarily causes decreased height of the affected individual i.e., there is short stature of the patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mseleni joint disease is endemic to the northern Kwazulu Natal area in South Africa.
  • The condition is characterized by chronic joint pain and swelling, typically involving large joints such as the hip.
  • It has been associated with the consumption of contaminated maize containing mycotoxins produced by fungi.
  • It is more common in females.
  • It leads to severe short stature.

choices.text: Osteochondral fracture
Osteochondritis dissecans

questions.text: The following is the commonest cause of loose body in knee joint:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Osteoarthritis

 

Option A)

 

LOOSE BODIES

 

  • Commonest cause of loose bodies in knee joint is osteochondritis dissecans in young.
  • Osteoarthritis is commonest cause in elderly and overall.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Osteochondral fracture. An osteochondral fracture involves damage to both the cartilage and the underlying bone in a joint.

 

Option C. Synovial chondromatosis. Synovial chondromatosis is a benign condition where cartilaginous nodules or loose bodies develop within the synovial membrane of a joint.

 

Option D. Osteochondritis dissecans. Osteochondritis dissecans (OCD) is a joint condition where a small segment of bone and its overlying articular cartilage lose blood supply.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease characterized by the gradual breakdown of cartilage in the joints and subsequent changes in the underlying bone.
  • It is the most common cause of loose body in knee joint in elderly patients and overall.

choices.text: All are correct

questions.text:
Indications of arthroplasty are:

 

  1. Osteoarthritis
  2. Rheumatoid arthritis
  3. Ankylosing spondylitis
  4. Gout
  5. Fracture neck femur
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All are correct

 

Option D)

 

INDICATIONS OF ARTHROPLASTY

 

  • Arthroplasty can be done for any disease any joint except active infection.
  • Important conditions for which arthroplasty is indicated are:
    • severe osteoarthritis of the hip and knee joints
    • advanced rheumatoid arthritis with disabling pain
    • quiescent destructive tuberculous arthritis
    • non-united femoral neck fracture
    • correction of deformities like hallux valgus
    • avascular necrosis

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Arthroplasty can be done for any disease any joint except active infection.
  • It can be done in Osteoarthritis, Rheumatoid arthritis, Ankylosing spondylosis, Gout and fracture neck femur.

questions.text: Bechterew’s Disease is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ankylosing Spondylitis

 

Option B)

 

BECHTEREW’S DISEASE

 

  • Bechterew's Disease, also known as Ankylosing Spondylitis (AS), is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy, a genetically determined generalized chronic inflammatory disease that primarily affects the axial skeleton (sacroiliac joint and spine) with variable involvement of root joints (shoulder and hip) and peripheral joints.
  • The involvement is an enthesopathy.
  • Etiology and Pathogenesis:
    •  > 90% of AS patients are HLA-B27 positive whereas only 10% of normal population is HLA-B27 positive.
    • 1–6% of adults inheriting HLA-B27 have been found to have AS.
    • The enthesis, the site of ligamentous attachment to bone, is the primary site of pathology in AS particularly in pelvis and spine.
    • It is associated with prominent edema of adjacent bone marrow and is characterized by erosive lesions that eventually undergo ossification.
    • Sacroiliitis is the earliest manifestation with features of both enthesitis and synovitis.
    • Peripheral arthritis of AS can show synovial hyperplasia, lymphoid infiltration and pannus but lacks exuberant synovial villi, fibrin deposits, ulcers, and accumulation of plasma cells seen in rheumatoid arthritis.
    • Central cartilaginous erosion, caused by proliferation of subchondral granulation tissue are common in AS but rare in RA.
    • TNF and cytokine play central role in pathogenesis.
    • There is autoimmunity to cartilage proteoglycan aggrecan.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Rheumatoid Arthritis. Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic autoimmune disease that primarily affects the joints. It involves inflammation of the synovium, which can lead to joint damage and deformities. Unlike Bechterew's Disease (AS), RA typically affects smaller joints, such as those in the hands and feet.

 

Option C. Paget’s disease. Paget's disease of bone, also known as osteitis deformans is a chronic disorder that results in enlarged and deformed bones. It typically affects the spine, pelvis, long bones, and skull. Unlike Bechterew's Disease, Paget's disease involves abnormal bone remodelling, leading to increased bone density and potential deformities.

 

Option D. Osteopetrosis. Osteopetrosis or Albers-Schonber disease, is a rare genetic disorder characterized by abnormally dense bones. It results from impaired bone resorption, leading to increased bone mass. This condition can cause bone fractures, anemia, and neurological complications. Osteopetrosis is distinct from Bechterew's Disease, which is an inflammatory arthritis affecting the spine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bechterew's Disease, also known as Ankylosing Spondylitis (AS), is a type of inflammatory arthritis that primarily affects the spine and sacroiliac joints.
  • Over time, it can lead to fusion of the vertebrae, causing stiffness and reduced mobility in the spine. AS is often associated with the HLA-B27 genetic marker.

questions.text: Sausage digits are seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Psoriatic arthritis

 

Option C)

 

SAUSAGE DIGITS

 

  • The term sausage digit refers to the clinical and radiologic appearance of diffuse fusiform swelling of a digit due to soft tissue inflammation from underlying arthritis or dactylitis. 

 

 

  • The common causes of sausage digit are:
    • psoriatic arthropathy
    • osteomyelitis
    • sickle cell disease
    • sarcoidosis
    • tuberculous dactylitis (spina ventosa) 
    • leukemia
    • syphilitic dactylitis
    • gout

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lyme arthritis. Lyme arthritis is a manifestation of Lyme disease, which is caused by the bacterium Borrelia burgdorferi, transmitted through the bite of infected ticks. Joint involvement in Lyme arthritis often presents as intermittent episodes of swelling, commonly affecting large joints like the knee. Affected knees may have very large effusions with warmth, but they are not particularly painful with range of motion or weight bearing. Baker’s cysts may be present in the knees.

 

 

Option B. Osteoarthritis. Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease characterized by the gradual breakdown of cartilage in the joints. It is typically associated with aging and wear and tear on the joints. Osteoarthritis is considerably more prevalent in the distal than the proximal interphalangeal joints. The soft tissue swelling around the DIP joint associated with osteophyte formation is called a Heberden node and that around the PIP joint is called a Bouchard node.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Psoriatic arthritis is an inflammatory arthritis that occurs in some individuals with psoriasis, a chronic skin condition.
  • "Sausage digits" refer to the characteristic swelling of an entire digit, giving it a sausage-like appearance.
  • This can be seen in the context of dactylitis, a hallmark feature of psoriatic arthritis.

choices.text: Involvement of DIP joint
More common in males

questions.text: True about psoriatic arthritis are all expect:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) More common in males

 

Option C)

 

PSORIATIC ARTHRITIS

 

  • Epidemiology:
    • Prevalence of psoriasis is 1-2% and psoriatic arthritis develops only in 5-10% of cases.
    • It is associated with HLA DR7, HLA-Cω6.
    • A9 allele and KIR (killer immunoglobin like receptor) alleles are associated.
    • Rheumatoid factor is almost always negative.
    • 60% of those with spondylitis or sacroiliitis have HLA-B27.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Sex ratio is 1:1 and usual age of onset is 30–50 years.
    • Five patterns of joint involvement are seen:
      • Arthritis of DIP joint
      • Asymmetrical oligoarthritis
      • Symmetrical polyarthritis similar to RA
      • Axial involvement (spine and sacroiliac joint)
      • Arthritis mutilans

 

 

  • Nail changes occurs in 90% patients of psoriatic arthritis (40% in patient without arthritis).
  • Dactylitis, enthesitis and tenosynovitis are also common.
  • Shortening of digits (telescoping), because of underlying osteolysis is characteristic of psoriatic arthritis.
  • Fibrous and bony ankylosis of small joints (greater tendency than RA).
  • Almost any peripheral joint can be involved.
  • Treatment:
    • Anti-TNF-α agents, e.g. etanercept and infliximab are newer drugs and are effective even in longstanding cases (to previous therapy) and extensive skin lesion.
    • Methotrexate is drug of choice.
    • Other effective agents are sulfasalazine, cyclosporine, retinoic acid and psoralen and UV-A (PUVA).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. HLA-Cω6 association. True. Psoriatic arthritis has a strong association with certain human leukocyte antigen (HLA) genes, including HLA-Cω6.

 

Option B. Involvement of DIP. True. Psoriatic arthritis is known for starting at the DIP joints, which are the points closest to the fingernails and toenails.

 

Option D. DOC is methotrexate. True. Psoriatic arthritis is an autoimmune condition that causes chronic inflammation of the skin, joints, and connective tissues. This typically causes symptoms such as pain, stiffness, and swelling. Methotrexate is a disease-modifying anti-rheumatic drug (DMARD) which affects immune system activity and can reduce inflammation, pain, and swelling in Psoriatic Arthritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Psoriatic arthritis is found equally in both sexes.
  • The sex ratio for psoriatic arthritis is 1:1.

questions.text: Deforming polyarthritis is associated with all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Behçet's syndrome

 

Option C)

 

BEHCET DISEASE

 

  • Behcet disease is an auto-inflammatory systemic vasculitis of unknown etiology.
  • It is characterized by mucocutaneous manifestations, including recurrent oral and genital ulcerations, ocular manifestations, especially chronic relapsing uveitis, and systemic vasculitis involving arteries and veins of all sizes.
  • Exposure to infectious agents, especially hypersensitivity to Streptococcus sanguinis antigens, has suggested a pathological role.
  • Behcet disease usually affects young adults of 20 to 40 years of age and is less frequently seen in children.  
  • Both genders are equally affected by the disease; a male predominance is observed.
  • It involves auto-inflammatory vasculitis of arteries and veins of all sizes and types. 
  • Vasculitic lesions in Behcet disease lack necrotizing vasculitis or giant cell formation.
  • Venular involvement and formation of pulmonary and arterial aneurysms are unique to Behcet disease. 
  • Patients with Behcet disease lack specific auto-antibodies.
  • Musculoskeletal manifestations:
    • Inflammatory, non-erosive, non-deforming arthritis in 50% of patients. 
    • It is usually oligoarthritis that is symmetric or asymmetric, but polyarthritis and monoarthritis can also be seen.
    • Joint involvement is peripheral, and spine involvement or sacroiliitis is not usually seen, differentiating it from HLA-B27-associated erosive sacroiliitis.
    • The knees are the most commonly involved joint, followed by ankles, wrists, and elbows.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Rheumatoid arthritis. Rheumatoid arthritis is a classic example of deforming polyarthritis. It is characterized by symmetric inflammation of multiple joints, leading to joint deformities over time.

 

Option B. Psoriatic Arthritis. Psoriatic arthritis is associated with joint inflammation and can lead to joint deformities. It commonly occurs in individuals with psoriasis and can affect various joints, including the fingers and toes.

 

Option D. Ankylosing spondylitis. Ankylosing spondylitis primarily affects the spine and sacroiliac joints. This also causes joint erosion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The arthritis of Behçet's syndrome is not deforming and affects knees and ankles.
  • Rheumatoid arthritis, psoriatic arthritis, ankylosing spondylitis, neuropathic arthropathy, etc. cause deforming arthritis.

choices.text: Femoral component during flexion
Femoral component during extension
Inferior pole during flexion
Superior pole during extension

questions.text: Patellar Clunk Syndrome scar is present at superior pole of patella and impinges on:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Femoral component during extension

 

Option B)

 

PATELLAR CLUNK SYNDROME

 

  • Patellar Clunk Syndrome is a condition characterized by an audible clunk/catching sensation heard when knee is brought to extended position from flexed position.
  • It is felt on the superior pole of patella.
  • It commonly occurs after Total Knee Replacement surgery.
  • It is thought to be due to adhesions formation that impinges on femoral component after the surgery in which the Knee gets trapped on extension.
  • Clinical Features: Audible/Palpable clunk sensation, limited range of motion, pain/discomfort, Swelling.
  • Treatment includes physical therapy, NSAIDs and arthroscopic adhesions removal.
  • If symptoms are severe, it requires resection of fibrous nodule (arthroscopic/open).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Femoral component during flexion. Patellar Clunk Syndrome scar is present at superior pole of patella and does not impinging on femoral component during flexion.

 

Option C. Inferior pole during flexion. Scar tissue at the inferior pole of the patella would not typically impinge on the femoral component during knee flexion. This is not consistent with Patellar Clunk Syndrome.

 

Option D. Superior pole during extension. This is not consistent with Patellar Clunk Syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patellar clunk syndrome is knee popping and catching due to fibrous nodule on superior pole of patella in TKR patients that impinges on femoral component on knee extension.

questions.text: While performing a total hip replacement, the surgeon found destruction of the articular cartilage and multiple wedge-shaped subchondral depressions. What is this called?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Osteonecrosis

 

Option C)

 

OSTEONECROSIS

 

  • Subchondral depressions indicate avascular necrosis = Osteonecrosis
  • Reduced blood supply causes:
    • Sclerosis
    • Subchondral depression
    • Cyst formation
    • Full blown arthritis

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Osteolysis. Osteolysis refers to the process of bone resorption or destruction. In the context of joint replacement, periprosthetic osteolysis can occur due to the release of wear particles from the prosthetic components, triggering an inflammatory response. Over time, this can lead to the breakdown of bone around the implant.

 

Option B. Osteomyelitis. Osteomyelitis is an infection of the bone that can occur due to the introduction of bacteria. It can cause inflammation, destruction of bone tissue, and sometimes the formation of abscesses. Osteomyelitis can be caused by bacteria entering the bone through trauma, surgery, or the bloodstream.

 

Option D. Osteogenesis. Osteogenesis refers to the formation or production of new bone tissue. This process is crucial for bone development, repair, and remodeling. Osteoblasts are cells responsible for bone formation, and osteogenesis plays a role in maintaining bone density and strength.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Destruction of articular cartilage and presence of the wedge-shaped subchondral depressions are characteristic of osteonecrosis, where impaired blood supply leads to the death of bone tissue.

choices.text: Corrective osteotomy for genu valgum
Medial patellofemoral ligament reconstruction
Bicondylar plating of proximal tibia fracture

questions.text: Patellar clunk syndrome is a known complication of which surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Total knee replacement

 

Option B)

 

PATELLAR CLUNK SYNDROME

 

  • It is knee popping and catching due to fibrous nodule on superior pole of patella in TKR patients that impinges on femoral component on knee extension.
  • It is characterized by an audible clunk/catching sensation heard when knee is brought to extended position from flexed position.
  • Clinical Features: Audible/Palpable clunk sensation, limited range of motion, pain/discomfort, Swelling.
  • If symptoms are severe, it requires resection of fibrous nodule (arthroscopic/open).
  • Treatment includes physical therapy, NSAIDs and arthroscopic adhesions removal.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Corrective osteotomy for genu valgum. Corrective osteotomy for genu valgum involves surgically realigning the bones to correct a deformity where the knee is deviated outward. Patellar clunk syndrome is not typically associated with this type of corrective osteotomy.

 

Option C. Medial patellofemoral ligament reconstruction. Medial patellofemoral ligament (MPFL) reconstruction is a surgical procedure to stabilize the patella and prevent dislocation. While complications can occur, patellar clunk syndrome is not a common issue following MPFL reconstruction.

 

Option D. Bicondylar plating of proximal tibia fracture.  Bicondylar plating of a proximal tibia fracture involves the use of a plate and screws to stabilize a fracture in the upper part of the tibia. Patellar clunk syndrome is not commonly associated with this type of fracture fixation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patellar clunk syndrome is a known complication of Total Knee replacement surgery.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles are seen on splitting tensor fascia lata during anterolateral approach before hip joint is exposed?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gluteus medius

 

Option B)

 

Muscles seen on splitting of tensor fascia lata during hip surgery:

 

  • Anterior approach: TFL and Sartorius
  • Anterolateral approach: TFL and gluteus medius
  • Posterior approach: Gluteus maximus split

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Gluteus Maximus. This muscle is not typically involved in the anterolateral approach.

 

Option C. Gluteus Minimus. This muscle can be seen on the splitting of the TFL muscle in the anterolateral approach.

 

Option D. Superior Gemellus. This muscle is not directly involved in the anterolateral approach. It is a smaller muscle located deep in the pelvis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Muscle seen on splitting tensor fascia lata during anterolateral approach before hip joint is exposed is Gluteus medius.

choices.text: Magnitude of correction achieved is greater than 30 degree
Indicated in unicompartmental osteoarthritis
Recurrence is a long-term complication

questions.text: All of the following statements about High Tibial Osteotomy are true, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Magnitude of correction achieved is greater than 30 degrees.

 

Option A)

 

HIGH TIBIAL OSTEOTOMY

 

  • High tibial osteotomy is a procedure done to treat conditions like Osteoarthritis of knee.
  • A cut is made in the upper part of tibia and is realigned to redistribute the forces on the knee joint and is done through cancellous part of the bone.
  • It is done in Osteoarthritis in which one compartment is affected.
  • Most common deformity in patients with OA of knee is a varus position, which causes stress to be concentrated medially, accelerating degenerative changes in medial part of joint.
  • Valgus deformity causes accelerated changes on lateral compartment (Seen in rheumatoid arthritis).

 

 

 

  • Principle:
    • Biomechanical rationale for proximal tibial osteotomy in patients with unicompartmental osteoarthritis of knee is unloading of involved joint compartment by correcting the malalignment and redistributing the stresses on the knee joint.
    • Osteotomy (corrective) is performed through cancellous bone near joint line to offer advantages of higher healing rates and to achieve better joint line inclination and limb alignment.
    • In a varus knee, correction of 8–10 degrees of anatomical valgus is associated with best prognosis while knees left with residual varus have a less satisfactory result and high chances of recurrences.

 

 

  • Indications:
    • Pain and disability resulting from OA that significantly interfere with high demand employment or recreation.
    • Evidence on weight bearing radiographs of degenerative arthritis that is confined to one compartment with a corresponding varus or valgus deformity.
    • The ability of patient to carry out a rehabilitation program.
    • Good vascular status without serious arterial insufficiency or large varicosity.
  • Contraindications:
    • More than 20 degrees correction needed.
    • Narrowing of lateral compartment cartilage space
    • Lateral tibial subluxation of > 1 cm
    • Medial compartment bone loss of > 3 mm
    • Flexion contracture of > 15 degrees
    • Knee flexion movement of < 90 degrees
    • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Complications:
    • Compartment syndrome
    • Recurrence (5–30%) of deformity
    • Infection
    • Stiffness of knee
    • Peroneal nerve palsy
    • Nonunion of osteotomy

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Indicated in unicompartmental osteoarthritis. True. High Tibial Osteotomy is indeed indicated in cases of unicompartmental osteoarthritis, where the arthritis is primarily affecting one compartment of the knee joint.

 

Option C. Performed through cancellous bone. True. Hip Tibial Osteotomy is typically performed through the cancellous bone of the proximal tibia. The bone is cut and realigned to unload the affected compartment of the knee.

 

Option D. Recurrence is a long term complication. True. Recurrence of deformity is a potential long-term complication of High Tibial Osteotomy. Over time, factors such as healing and remodelling can influence the achieved correction, and in some cases, recurrence of deformity may occur.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • High Tibial Osteotomy (HTO) is a surgical procedure used to correct deformities in the knee, typically in the case of unicompartmental osteoarthritis.
  • However, the magnitude of correction achieved in HTO is generally not as large as 30 degrees, about 8-10 of anatomical valgus achieved in a varus knee gives a good prognosis.  
  • High Tibial Osteotomy is more commonly performed within a range of 5 to 15 degrees of correction.
  • It is performed through the cutting of the cancellous bone.
  • Recurrence of the deformity is a long-term complication, that is seen in about 5-30% cases.

questions.text: Glucosamine supplementation is given in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Arthritis

 

Option A)

 

CLASSIFICATION SYSTEM AND STAGE WISE MANAGEMENT FOR OA KNEE

 

  1. Initial treatment is always conservative (exercise and glucosamines are preferred).
  2. Clinical picture is more significant than radiology or X-ray changes.
  3. If activities of daily living are affected, surgery is advised.
  4. Surgery for young is HTO (if not contraindicated). If contraindicated, TKR is performed.
  5. Surgery for elderly (≥ 65 years) is TKR.
  6. High Tibial Osteotomy
  7. Total Knee Replacement
  8. Usually stage 2 onwards in elderly, TKR is finally carried out.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Diabetes.  It does not seem to have much effect on blood sugar for patients with diabetes.

 

Option C. Cataract. Glucosamine is not typically used in the management of cataracts. Cataracts involve clouding of the eye's lens, and treatment approaches generally focus on surgical intervention when the cataract significantly impairs vision.

 

Option D. Asthma. Glucosamine is not a standard treatment for asthma. Asthma is a respiratory condition characterized by inflammation and narrowing of the airways. Treatment for asthma usually involves bronchodilators and anti-inflammatory medications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Glucosamine is a natural compound found in cartilage and is commonly used as a dietary supplement for the management of osteoarthritis.
  • It helps support joint health by providing the building blocks for the synthesis and repair of cartilage.

questions.text:
True about osteoarthritis is/are: 

 

  1. Common in knee than hip
  2. Decreased thickness of subchondral bone
  3. Characterized by increased water content
  4. Decrease in proteoglycans
  5. It is a non-inflammatory arthritis
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 3, 4, 5

 

Option D)
 

OSTEOARTHRITIS

 

  • Osteoarthritis is a common non-inflammatory type of arthritis that presents with age-related degeneration of the articular cartilage.
  • It classically presents with joint pain and loss of function.
  • It is more commonly seen in knees, followed by the hips.
  • Etiology:
    • Increased risk with age, female gender, obesity, trauma (occupational/sports-related), anatomical factors, muscle weakness.
    • Primary OA is the most common and is diagnosed without any predisposing trauma.
    • Secondary OA occurs with a pre-existing joint abnormality due to trauma, congenital joint disorders, inflammatory arthritis, avascular necrosis, infectious arthritis, Wilson’s disease etc.
  • Pathogenesis:
    • Mechanical, age-related degeneration of articular cartilage
    • Inflammation with adequate repair mediated by chondrocytes
    • Presence of risk factors, mechanical stress and abnormal joint mechanics leads to release of pro-inflammatory markers and protease that mediate joint destruction.
    • The earliest change is the fibrillation, irregularity and focal erosion of the articular cartilage.
    • Microscopically, the collagen matrix damages, causing chondrocytes to proliferate and form clusters.
    • Changes to hypertrophic chondrocytes causes outgrowing of cartilage that ossifies and forms osteophytes.
    • Improper collagen mineralization causes subchondral bone thickening.
  • Clinical features:
    • Pain in the joints which increase with activity and improves with rest
    • Asymmetric joint involvement.
    • Loss of knee cartilage medially causing Genu varum deformity.
    • Bony joint enlargement
    • Limited ROM
  • Osteoarthritis characteristically involves distal interphalangeal joint (Heberden’s node), proximal interphalangeal joint (Bouchard’s node), 1st carpometacarpal joint of hand with sparing of metacarpophalangeal joint and wrist joint.
  • Pattern of Joint Involvement:
    • Monoarticular/Pauciarticular: Knee > Hip
    • Polyarticular: DIP
  • Overall DIP commonest

 

 

  • Radiological features:
  • Asymmetrical loss of Cartilage Causing Narrowing of Joint Space (earliest feature)
  • Sclerosis of subchondral bone under the area of cartilage loss
  • Cystic lesion close to articular surface
  • Osteophytes at the margins of joint
  • Loose bodies and deformities can be there

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Osteoarthritis is the non-inflammatory arthritis.
  • It is more common in knee than in hip.
  • It is characterized by increased water content and decrease in proteoglycans.
  • There is increased thickness of the subchondral bone due to improper mineralization of the collagen.

questions.text:
About Osteoarthritis, choose the correct statement: 

 

  1. Thickening of synovial membrane is one of the earliest feature of the disease
  2. Weight bearing is a common etiology underlying ankle OA
  3. In India, knee OA is more common than hip OA
  4. Hip arthrodesis if done, can decrease the pain associated, but will cause a decrease in joint movement
  5. MCP joint is spared in OA
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2, 3, 4, 5

 

Option D)

 

OSTEOARTHRITIS

 

  • Osteoarthritis is a common non-inflammatory type of arthritis that presents with age-related degeneration of the articular cartilage.
  • It classically presents with joint pain and loss of function.
  • It is more commonly seen in knees, followed by the hips.
  • Etiology:
    • Increased risk with age, female gender, obesity, trauma (occupational/sports-related), anatomical factors, muscle weakness.
    • Primary OA is the most common and is diagnosed without any predisposing trauma.
    • Secondary OA occurs with a pre-existing joint abnormality due to trauma, congenital joint disorders, inflammatory arthritis, avascular necrosis, infectious arthritis, Wilson’s disease etc.
  • Pathogenesis:
    • Mechanical, age-related degeneration of articular cartilage
    • Inflammation with adequate repair mediated by chondrocytes
    • Presence of risk factors, mechanical stress and abnormal joint mechanics leads to release of pro-inflammatory markers and protease that mediate joint destruction.
    • The earliest change is the fibrillation, irregularity and focal erosion of the articular cartilage.
    • Microscopically, the collagen matrix damages, causing chondrocytes to proliferate and form clusters.
    • Changes to hypertrophic chondrocytes causes outgrowing of cartilage that ossifies and forms osteophytes.
    • Improper collagen mineralization causes subchondral bone thickening.
  • Clinical features:
    • Pain in the joints which increase with activity and improves with rest
    • Asymmetric joint involvement.
    • Loss of knee cartilage medially causing Genu varum deformity.
    • Bony joint enlargement
    • Limited ROM
  • Osteoarthritis characteristically involves distal interphalangeal joint (Heberden’s node), proximal interphalangeal joint (Bouchard’s node), 1st carpometacarpal joint of hand with sparing of metacarpophalangeal joint and wrist joint.
  • Pattern of Joint Involvement:
    • Monoarticular/Pauciarticular: Knee > Hip
    • Polyarticular: DIP
  • Overall DIP commonest

 

 

  • Radiological features:
    • Asymmetrical loss of Cartilage Causing Narrowing of Joint Space (earliest feature)
    • Sclerosis of subchondral bone under the area of cartilage loss
    • Cystic lesion close to articular surface
    • Osteophytes at the margins of joint
    • Loose bodies and deformities can be there

 

 

  • Treatment:
    • Maintain movement and muscle strength by physiotherapy and graded muscle exercise.
    • Protects the joint from overload by giving rest and weight reduction.
    • Correction of deformities if present.
    • Thermal modalities, analgesic medication, wedged insoles, Orthosis and arthroscopic debridement and lavage.
    • Progressive joint destruction require joint replacement in elderly and HTO in young.

 

Explanation:
