  1. Thickening of synovial membrane is one of the earliest feature of the disease. False. The earliest feature of the disease is the fibrillation, irregularity and focal erosion of the articular cartilage.
  2. Weight bearing is a common etiology underlying ankle OA. True. Several factors can contribute to the development of ankle OA, including injury, genetics, and mechanical stress. Weight bearing is a significant mechanical stressor on the ankle joint. Over time, repetitive loading and impact on the joint during weight-bearing activities can lead to wear and tear of the cartilage in the ankle joint, eventually resulting in the development of osteoarthritis in the ankle.
  3. In India, knee OA is more common than hip OA. True. Osteoarthritis of the knee is more commonly seen than that of the hip joint.
  4. Hip arthrodesis if done, can decrease the pain associated, but will cause a decrease in joint movement. True. Arthrodesis is another surgical intervention in cases of OA. It reduces the joint pain but sacrifices the joint's articular function, so it is performed on small joints, like wrists and ankles.
  5. MCP joint is spared in OA. True. MCP and wrist joint are spared in OA. DIP, PIP and 1st CMC joint are commonly involved.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The earliest feature of the disease is the fibrillation, irregularity and focal erosion of the articular cartilage.
  • In India, knee osteoarthritis is more common than hip osteoarthritis.
  • Weight bearing is a common etiology underlying ankle osteoarthritis.
  • Hip arthrodesis if done, can decrease the pain associated, but will cause a decrease in joint movement.
  • MCP joint is spared in Osteoarthritis.

questions.text: Following X-ray changes are seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) OA

 

Option A)

 

OSTEOARTHRITIS

 

  • Osteoarthritis characteristically involves distal interphalangeal joint (Heberden’s node), proximal interphalangeal joint (Bouchard’s node), 1st carpometacarpal joint of hand with sparing of metacarpophalangeal joint and wrist joint.
  • The given X-ray showing subchondral sclerosis at PIP and DIP along with osteophytes is suggestive of Osteoarthritis.
  •  In Osteoarthritis, MCP is spared and in Rheumatoid Arthritis, DIP is spared.

 

 

Hand joints involved in OA (H = Herberden’s Node and B = Bouchard’s node)

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Rheumatoid Arthritis. Joint space narrowing can occur due to cartilage destruction, but typically not as prominent as in OA. It reflects joint damage. The characteristic deformities seen in the RA hand are Z-deformity of the wrist and digits, swan neck deformity of PIP and DIP joints, Boutonniere deformity, swan neck deformity of the thumb.

 

 

 

 

Option C. Psoriasis. Joint space narrowing can occur but less common than OA. Erosion and joint deformity are more common. Radiologically, DIP joint involvement classically presents as pencil cup deformity. There is marginal joint erosion with bony proliferation, osteolysis of phalanges and metacarpals, and telescoping of the digits.

 

 

Pencil-in-cup deformity

 

Option D. Pseudogout. Joint space narrowing is possible due to cartilage damage. Pseudogout has many features of osteoarthritis with an unusual distribution, for example, it tends to be symmetric in distribution and involve non-weight bearing joints. In the hands, it mainly involve the intercarpal and metacarpophalangeal joints. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given X-ray shows Heberden’s nodes and Bouchard’s nodes in the hand, which are classical of osteoarthritis.
  • DIP involvement is seen.
  • There is subchondral sclerosis at the PIP and DIP joints along with osteophytes.
  • The MCP joint is spared in OA.

choices.text: Both A and B

questions.text: In patients with osteoarthritis of knee joint, atrophy occurs most commonly in which muscle:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Quadriceps only

 

Option A)

 

OSTEOARTHRITIS

 

  • Quadriceps is the most common muscle involved in OA.
  • Due to decreased loading of painful extremity, quadriceps weakness is common in patients of osteoarthritis of knee.
  • Most importantly vastus medialis is affected.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Hamstring Muscle. The hamstrings are a group of three muscles located at the back of the thigh. While muscle atrophy can occur in the hamstrings, it is often less prominent compared to the quadriceps in knee osteoarthritis.

 

Option D. Gastrocnemius. The gastrocnemius is a muscle located in the calf. While muscle changes can occur in the lower extremities, atrophy of the gastrocnemius is not a primary feature of osteoarthritis of the knee.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In osteoarthritis of the knee joint, the most common muscle affected by atrophy is the quadriceps.
  • Muscle atrophy in osteoarthritis is often related to pain, joint dysfunction, and disuse.
  • Strengthening exercises and rehabilitation focused on the quadriceps are commonly employed to improve muscle function and alleviate symptoms in individuals with knee osteoarthritis.

choices.text: Symmetrically large joints
Distal interphalangeal joints

questions.text: Heberden’s arthropathy affects:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Distal interphalangeal joints.

 

Option D)

 

HEBERDEN’S ARTHROPATHY

 

  • Localized (Monoarticular and Pauci-articular) OA involves:

 

 

  • In the OA of the hand, the DIP joint is involved, which presents as Heberden’s node.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lumbar Spine. Heberden's arthropathy does not typically affect the lumbar spine. Lumbar spine osteoarthritis can be associated with radicular pain above the knee. If radicular symptoms move below the knee, nerve root compression or irritation is likely.

 

Option B. Symmetrically large joints. Symmetric involvement of large joints is present in rheumatoid arthritis. Heberden's arthropathy is not characterized by symmetric involvement of large joints.

 

Option C. Sacroiliac Joints. Heberden's arthropathy is not associated with the sacroiliac joints. The SI joint is involved in the ankylosing spondylitis and presents as the pain and inflammation in the joint or sacroiliitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Heberden's arthropathy is a presentation of osteoarthritis that primarily affects the distal interphalangeal joints of the fingers.
  • It is characterized by the development of bony nodules or nodes on these joints, leading to deformities and pain in the fingers.

choices.text: Commonly found in adult after 50 years
Heberden’s nodes are found
Lower limb deformity is seen
Ankylosis is seen

questions.text: True about osteoarthritis are all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ankylosis is seen

 

Option D)

 

OSTEOARTHRITIS

 

  • Ankylosis is very rare in OA. It is seen in inflammatory arthritis.
  • The sclerotic bone prevents fusion or ankylosis in osteoarthritis.
  • Only erosive osteoarthritis has erosions and ankylosis. 
  • Sclerotic changes are noted in OA, but ankylosis or erosions do not usually develop.
  • In the advanced stage of the disease, a collapse of the joint may occur; however, ankylosis does not usually occur in patients with primary osteoarthritis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Commonly found in adults after 50 years. True. Osteoarthritis is more commonly found in older adults, and the risk increases with age. However, it can also affect younger individuals, especially if they have predisposing factors.

 

Option B. Heberden’s nodes are found. This statement is true. Heberden's nodes are a characteristic feature of osteoarthritis, particularly affecting the DIP joints.

 

Option C. Lower limb deformity is seen. This statement is true. Osteoarthritis often affects weight-bearing joints such as the knees and hips, leading to deformities over time. In knees, the disease progression leads to varus deformity of the knee.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ankylosis is seen is the false statement.
  • Ankylosis is more commonly associated with conditions like rheumatoid arthritis, where there is inflammation and progressive joint damage.
  • Osteoarthritis typically does not lead to ankylosis; instead, it is characterized by the gradual degeneration of cartilage.

choices.text: Intra-articular hydrocortisone and physiotherapy

questions.text: Severe disability in primary osteoarthritis of hip is best managed by:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arthroplasty

 

Option B)

 

OSTEOARTHRITIS HIP TREATMENT

 

  • Total hip arthroplasty (THA) is often considered the gold standard for treating severe osteoarthritis of the hip, providing effective pain relief and restoring joint function.
  • In the early stages of osteoarthritis, joint-preserving procedures such as pelvic osteotomy (for insufficient acetabular coverage of the femur) or hip arthroscopy (for femoroacetabular impingement) may be considered depending on the patient’s underlying diagnosis.
  • These procedures are generally not recommended for patients with advanced degenerative changes.
  • Patients with advanced joint damage are best referred to consider the option of total hip replacement.
  • In a traditional hip replacement, the femoral head and damaged acetabulum are both removed and replaced with metal, plastic or ceramic components.
  • Cement may be used for fixation. 
  • This procedure is highly effective in minimizing pain and restoring function. 
  • The risks of complications and early revisions following replacement have diminished.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Arthrodesis. Arthrodesis involves the surgical fusion of the hip joint, eliminating movement. Arthrodesis is not typically the first-line treatment for osteoarthritis of the hip, especially considering the desire to preserve hip function in daily activities. It may be considered in the severe OA of the ankle and the wrist joints.

 

Option C. McMurray’s osteotomy. McMurray’s osteotomy is a surgical procedure involving the repositioning of the acetabulum to improve hip joint mechanics. It is not a commonly performed procedure for advanced osteoarthritis of the hip. It is done for the management of malunited femoral neck fracture or those fractures with non-union/delayed union.  

 

Option D. Intra- articular hydrocortisone and physiotherapy. Intra-articular injections of corticosteroids may be used to reduce inflammation, and physiotherapy aims to improve joint function and strength. This option is more appropriate for managing symptoms and mild to moderate osteoarthritis. In severe cases with significant disability, more aggressive interventions like surgery may be required.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Arthroplasty, specifically total hip arthroplasty (THA) is a well-established and effective surgical intervention for severe osteoarthritis of the hip.

questions.text: Proximal interphalangeal, distal interphalangeal and 1st carpometacarpal joint involvement and sparing of wrist is a feature of:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Osteoarthritis

 

Option D)

 

OSTEOARTHRITIS OF HAND

 

  • Involvement of PIP, DIP and 1st carpometacarpal joint of thumb with sparing of wrist and metacarpophalangeal joint is a characteristic of OA.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Rheumatoid arthritis. PIP are often involved in rheumatoid arthritis. DIP is typically spared in the early stages of Rheumatoid arthritis. 1st metacarpal joint is generally not the primary site of involvement in Rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Option B. Pseudogout. PIP can be affected but not as commonly as in RA. DIP may be involved. 1st carpometacarpal joint is uncommon in pseudogout.

 

Option C. Psoriatic Arthropathy. PIP may be involved. DIP is commonly affected, especially in psoriatic arthritis. 1st carcometcarpal is generally spared.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Involvement of PIP, DIP and 1st carpometacarpal joint of thumb with sparing of wrist and metacarpophalangeal joint is characteristic of OA.

choices.text: Total knee replacement
High tibial osteotomy

questions.text: A 62-year-old Male complaints of pain bilateral knees, R > L. He has difficulty in climbing stairs, squatting, sitting cross legged. His quadriceps muscle is wasted. On Right Knee X-ray, there is subchondral sclerosis, tibial spine spiking, obliterated medial joint space and reduced lateral joint space. AHLBACK grade 2 stage is present. Next step is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Conservative

 

Option A)

 

  • In this case, next step is asked that will be a trial of conservative management.
  • If next best step would have been asked, then TKR (Total Knee Replacement) would have been preferred.

 

AHLBACK CLASSIFICATION OF OSTEOARTHRITIS

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Arthroscopy. Arthroscopy involves using a camera to visualize and potentially treat the interior of a joint. Arthroscopy is generally more beneficial for specific conditions like meniscal tears or cartilage defects. In advanced osteoarthritis, where there is significant joint space narrowing and sclerosis, arthroscopy may not be the primary treatment.

 

Option C. Total Knee Replacement. TKR involves replacing the damaged knee joint with a prosthetic joint. Total knee replacement is often the most appropriate intervention to provide pain relief and restore joint function.

 

Option D. High Tibial Osteotomy. High tibial osteotomy involves repositioning the upper part of the tibia to shift weight away from the damaged part of the knee joint. High tibial osteotomy is more commonly considered in cases where there is isolated medial compartment osteoarthritis and malalignment, and the patient is young.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Total knee replacement is a well-established and effective surgical intervention for advanced osteoarthritis, providing significant pain relief and improved joint function.
  • Since in the given question, next step is asked, so that will be a trial of conservative management.
  • If next best step would have been asked, then TKR would have been preferred.

questions.text:
All are features of inflammatory arthritis except:

 

  1. Morning stiffness
  2. X-ray showing sclerosis
  3. Elevated ESR
  4. Weight gain
  5. Swelling of joints
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Only 2 & 4

 

Option C)

 

INFLAMMATORY ARTHRITIS

 

 

Explanation:

 

  • Inflammatory arthritis is a type of arthritis characterized by inflammation in the joints.

 

  1. Morning stiffness: Morning stiffness is a common symptom of inflammatory arthritis. It typically lasts longer than 30 minutes and tends to improve with movement throughout the day. So, this option is not a feature that distinguishes inflammatory arthritis.
  2. X-ray showing sclerosis: Sclerosis refers to abnormal hardening or thickening of tissue, and it's not a typical feature of inflammatory arthritis. Instead, joint erosion, joint space narrowing, and bone deformities are commonly seen on X-rays of joints affected by inflammatory arthritis.
  3. Elevated ESR: Elevated ESR is a marker of inflammation and is commonly seen in inflammatory arthritis. Inflammatory processes within the body cause an increase in ESR, making this option consistent with inflammatory arthritis.
  4. Weight gain: Weight gain is not a typical feature of inflammatory arthritis. In fact, individuals with inflammatory arthritis may experience weight loss due to decreased appetite or the systemic effects of inflammation.
  5. Swelling of joints: Joint swelling is a hallmark feature of inflammatory arthritis. Inflammation in the joint lining causes fluid accumulation, leading to joint swelling or effusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Morning stiffness is a common feature of inflammatory arthritis due to joint inflammation.
  • Elevated ESR is a common marker of inflammation and is often seen in inflammatory arthritis.
  • Swelling of joints is a hallmark feature of inflammatory arthritis due to synovial inflammation and effusion.
  • X-ray showing Sclerosis and weight gain is not a feature of inflammatory arthritis, instead there is evidence of joint erosion, joint space narrowing and bony deformities, and the patients often tends to lose weight due to decreased appetite or systemic effects of inflammation.

questions.text:
True about Boutonnieres deformity is/are: 

 

  1. Rupture of extensor tendon
  2. Initially joints are mobile followed by rigidity
  3. Flexion at PIP joint and extension at DIP
  4. Seen in cases of osteoarthritis
  5. Rupture of flexor tendon
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3

 

Option B)

 

BOUTONNIERE DEFORMITY

 

  • Boutonniere deformity is the flexion contracture of PIP joints and hyperextension of DIP joints.
  • It is due to rupture of central slip of extensor tendon at the middle phalanx.

 

 

Explanation:

 

  1. Rupture of extensor tendon: This is true. Boutonniere deformity often occurs due to a rupture of the central slip of the extensor tendon at the middle phalanx level.
  2. Initially joints are mobile followed by rigidity: This is also true. Initially, there might be some mobility at the involved joints, but over time, the deformity can become rigid.
  3. Flexion at PIP joint and extension at DIP: This is true. In Boutonniere deformity, there is flexion at the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint and extension at the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint.
  4. Seen in cases of osteoarthritis: This is not typically associated with osteoarthritis. Boutonniere deformity is commonly seen in conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis, trauma, or congenital conditions affecting the extensor mechanism.
  5. Rupture of flexor tendon: This is incorrect. Boutonniere deformity is primarily caused by a rupture of the extensor tendon, not the flexor tendon.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Boutonniere deformity occurs due to rupture of extensor tendon.
  • Initially the joints are mobile, later becomes rigid.
  • It involves the flexion PIP joint and extension at DIP.

choices.text: Swan neck deformity

questions.text: In which of the following deformities is the distal interphalangeal joint flexed and proximal interphalangeal joint extended?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Swan neck deformity

 

Option B)

 

SWAN NECK DEFORMITY

 

  • Swan-neck deformity is the hyperextension of PIP joints with compensatory flexion of the distal interphalangeal joints.
  • There is also reciprocal flexion of the MCP joint.
  • This occurs as a result of an imbalance of the extensor mechanism of the digits.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Boutonniere deformity. This involves flexion contracture of PIP joints and hyperextension of DIP joints due to rupture of extensor tendon.

 

 

Option C. Z deformity. This involves radial deviation of the wrist with ulnar deviation of the digits, often with palmar subluxation of proximal phalanges.

 

 

Option D. Claw hand. Claw Hand is a deformity with hyperextension of the metacarpophalengeal (MCP) joints and flexion of the interphalengeal (IP) joints due to weakness of the intrinsic muscles of the hand.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Deformities involving distal interphalangeal joint flexion and proximal interphalangeal joint extension is the swan neck deformity.

choices.text: Equally affects all regions

questions.text: Rheumatoid Arthritis affects which region of the spinal column?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cervical spine

 

Option A)

 

SPINAL INVOLVEMENT IN RHEUMATOID ARTHRITIS

 

  • Less commonly involved joints in rheumatoid arthritis are:
  • Upper cervical spine (facet joint) with Atlantoaxial subluxation: Commonest areas affected in axial skeleton
  • Hip joint
  • Temporomandibular joint
  • Subtalar and forefoot joints
  • Lumbar spine is usually spared in RA.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Thoracic spine. While RA can affect any joint, including those in the thoracic spine, it is less commonly involved compared to the cervical spine. Thoracic spine involvement may contribute to pain and stiffness in the mid-back region.

 

Option C. Lumbosacral Spine. RA rarely affects the lumbosacral spine. Lumbar spine is usually spared in RA.

 

Option D. Equally Affects all regions. Rheumatoid arthritis does not equally affect all regions of the spine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rheumatoid arthritis tends to have a predilection for the cervical spine, and its impact on this region can lead to various complications and challenges in the management of the disease.

choices.text: Fracture distal phalanx of great toe

questions.text: Hammer toe deformity is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rheumatoid arthritis

 

Option A)

 

HAMMER TOE

 

  • Flexion deformity of PIP with compensatory hyperextension of MCP joint.
  • It occurs commonly in the 2nd or 3rd or 4th toe.

 

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Fracture Distal phalanx of great toe. A fracture of the distal phalanx may not typically lead to a hammer toe deformity. The toe may appear misaligned, bent or at an unsual angle in case of a displaced fracture.

 

Option C. Bunion. Bunions and hammer toes can coexist, but they are distinct deformities. Bunions involve a deviation of the big toe toward the second toe, while hammer toes involve abnormal bending of the smaller toes.

 

Option D. Osteochondritis. Osteochondritis may not be directly associated with hammer toe deformities. Hammer toe deformities are often related to muscle and tendon imbalances rather than osteochondritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • While hammer toe deformities can have various causes, including biomechanical factors and inflammatory conditions, they are often seen in the context of rheumatoid arthritis due to joint inflammation and soft tissue changes.

questions.text: Abatacept is used for:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rheumatoid arthritis

 

Option A)

 

ABATACEPT

 

  • Abatacept (CTLA4Ig) is a fusion protein of the extracellular domain of the human cytotoxic T-lymphocyte-associated antigen 4 (CTLA-4) linked to a modified Fc of human immunoglobulin 1 (IgG1).
  • It binds to CD80 and CD86 receptors on APC.
  • It inhibits T cell activation by blocking CD80/86 interactions to CD28.
  • This inhibits T cells proliferation and B cell immunological response.
  • This normalizes inflammatory mediators in RA.
  • It plays an important role in the early stages of pathogenesis of RA.
  • Abatacept has shown efficacy in the treatment of active rheumatoid arthritis when used as monotherapy or in combination with conventional DMARDs in patients with an inadequate response to other conventional or biological DMARDs.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Ankylosing Spondylitis. Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic inflammatory arthritis that primarily affects the spine and sacroiliac joints.  Abatacept is not a first-line treatment for ankylosing spondylitis. It does not improve disease activity or function or other parameters in ankylosing spondylitis patients.

 

Option C. Osteoarthritis. Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease characterized by the breakdown of joint cartilage and underlying bone changes. Abatacept is not useful in treating osteoarthritis.

 

Option D. Systemic Lupus Erythematosus. SLE is a systemic autoimmune disease that can affect various organs and tissues. Abatacept has demonstrated efficacy in other autoimmune diseases, but in SLE, clinical trials have failed to achieve their primary outcome. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Abatacept is a disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD) that works by inhibiting T-cell activation and is approved for use in the treatment of moderate to severe rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: Most common cause of reactive arthritis:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) S. flexneri

 

Option C)

 

REACTIVE ARTHRITIS

 

  • Overall commonest cause of reactive arthritis is chlamydia.
  • Second common is Shigella flexneri.
  • Reactive arthritis usually develops following a bout with certain bacterial infections including Chlamydia, Salmonella, Shigella, Yersinia, and Campylobacter.
  • These bacteria usually cause gastrointestinal or genitourinary infections.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Staph. Aureus. Staphylococcus aureus is not a common cause of reactive arthritis. Reactive arthritis is more commonly associated with enteric organisms rather than Staphylococcus aureus.

 

Option B. Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a well-recognized cause of reactive arthritis, particularly in cases of genitourinary infections. Reactive arthritis following a gonococcal infection can involve joints, causing arthritis along with other manifestations.

 

Option D. E. coli. Reactive arthritis can occur after enteric infections, and E. coli is among the enteric organisms associated with this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Reactive arthritis is often linked to gastrointestinal or genitourinary infections, and organisms such as Shigella flexneri, Neisseria gonorrhoeae, and certain strains of Escherichia coli are recognized triggers for this type of arthritis.
  • However, Shigella flexneri is specifically highlighted as a common cause.

questions.text: Ankylosing spondylitis in associated with:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HLA-B27

 

Option A)

 

ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS

 

  • 90-95% of cases are positive for HLA-B27.
  • Although the mechanism by which HLAB-27 causes disease is unknown, several hypotheses have been postulated.
  • According to the arthritogenic peptide hypothesis, when HLA-B27 forms a bond with a peptide from a microbial source, it triggers a CD8 T cell response to a self-peptide with a similar structure to the microbial peptide.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. HLA-B-8. HLA-B8 is not a major genetic association with ankylosing spondylitis. This HLA allele is not strongly linked to AS. It may be associated with coeliac disease, autoimmune active chronic hepatitis, myasthenia gravis, Cushing's syndrome, and primary biliary cirrhosis.

 

Option C. HLA-DW4/DR4. HLA-DW4/DR4 is not a major association with ankylosing spondylitis. These specific HLA type is considered a prominent genetic markers for rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Option D. HLA-DR3. HLA-DR3 is not a major genetic association with ankylosing spondylitis. This HLA allele is strongly linked to insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HLA-B27 is strongly associated with ankylosing spondylitis, and its presence is a key diagnostic criterion for the condition.

choices.text: Most commonly involves the sacroiliac joints
Enthesitis is common
More common is males
Roentgenogram is the most sensitive investigation

questions.text: All are true about Marie-Strumpell disease except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Roentgenogram is the most sensitive investigation

 

Option D)

 

MARIE-STRUMPELL DISEASE

 

  • Males are affected more frequently than females (2:1 to 10:1)
  • Age of onset is between 15–25 years (late adolescence and early adulthood).
  • Essential diagnostic criteria is definite radiographic sacroiliitis.

 

MRI is the most sensitive investigation for Sacroiliitis.

SI Joint (more on iliac side of joint) is seen on MRI.

“Never diagnose ankylosing spondylitis without sacroiliitis”

The enthesis, the site of ligamentous attachment to bone is primary site of pathology in AS particularly in pelvis and spine.

It is associated with prominent edema of adjacent bone marrow and is characterized by erosive lesions that eventually undergo ossification.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Most commonly involves the sacroiliac joints. True. Ankylosing spondylitis typically involves the sacroiliac joints, and inflammatory changes are commonly observed in this region.

 

Option B. Enthesitis is common. True. Enthesitis, inflammation at the sites where tendons or ligaments insert into the bone, is a characteristic feature of ankylosing spondylitis.

 

Option C. More common is males. True. Ankylosing spondylitis has a strong male predominance. The males of age 15-25 are more commonly affected.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • MRI is the most sensitive investigation to make a diagnosis of ankylosing spondylitis because is shows the inflammatory changes in the SI joint which is the most commonly involved joint in AS.
  • While radiographic imaging, such as X-rays (roentgenogram), can reveal characteristic changes in the later stages of AS, it is not the most sensitive investigation, especially in the early stages.
  • MRI is often more sensitive for detecting early inflammatory changes.

questions.text: False about treatment of Charcots joint in diabetes mellitus is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Total ankle replacement

 

Option C)

 

CHARCOTS JOINT TREATMENT 

 

  • Treatment in Charcots joint in diabetes is important to preserve the bones of the foot and ankle function. 
  • Treatment of Charcots arthropathy is limitation of joint movements by bracing or casting, joint debridement (arthrocentesis) and fusion off joint (arthrodesis).
  • While total ankle replacement (TAR) is a treatment option for end-stage ankle arthritis, it is generally contraindicated or approached with extreme caution in Charcot's joint. 
  • The underlying neuropathy, poor bone quality, and increased risk of infection and loosening of components make TAR a poor choice for Charcot's arthropathy. 
  • The high failure rates and complications in neuropathic joints outweigh the potential benefits. 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Limitation of movements with bracing: Restricting joint movements with bracing is a common approach to manage and stabilize Charcot joints. This is a cornerstone of conservative management for Charcot's joint, especially in the acute phase. The goal is to offload the affected joint and prevent further destruction and deformity. Total contact casting (TCC) and various braces (e.g., Charcot Restraint Orthotic Walker - CROW boot) are commonly used.

 

Option B. Arthrodesis: Arthrodesis involves surgical fusion of a joint and is considered in cases of severe deformity or instability in Charcot joint. Arthrodesis is a common and often effective surgical option for stabilizing severely deformed or unstable Charcot joints, particularly in the midfoot or ankle, to create a stable, plantigrade foot for ambulation.

 

Option D. Arthrocentesis: It involves joint debridement. This is the aspiration of fluid from a joint, typically done to relieve pressure from effusion. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For the treatment of Charcots arthropathy, limitation of joint movements by bracing or casting, joint debridement (arthrocentesis) and arthrodesis are commonly performed.
  • Joint replacement surgeries are not advised for charcots joints. 
  • The underlying neuropathy, poor bone quality, compromised soft tissues, and altered biomechanics in Charcot's joint significantly increase the risk of complications such as loosening of the implant, infection, and periprosthetic fractures, leading to poor outcomes. While advancements are being made, it's not a standard or recommended treatment for Charcot's joint.

questions.text: Martel’s sign is seen in which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gouty arthritis

 

Option C)

 

MARTEL’S SIGN

 

  • During acute attack of gout, X-rays show only soft tissue swelling.
  • Chronic gout may result in joint space narrowing and secondary OA.
  • Tophi appear as characteristic punched out cysts or deep erosions with over hanging bony edges (Martel’s or G’ sign).
  • These well-defined erosions are larger and slightly further from joint margin than typical RA erosions.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Rheumatoid arthritis. It is a chronic autoimmune disease that primarily affects the synovium (lining of the joints), leading to joint inflammation, pain, and eventually joint damage. Rheumatoid arthritis is associated with Z-deformity, swan neck deformity, Boutonniere deformities of the fingers, windswept deformity of the toes, and hammer toe.

 

Option B. Osteoarthritis. Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease characterized by the breakdown of joint cartilage and underlying bone changes. Osteoarthritis is associated with heberden’s and bouchard’s nodes in the fingers.

 

Option D. Ochronosis. Ochronosis is a metabolic disorder associated with the accumulation of homogentisic acid. It is associated with skin and bone discoloration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tophi in the gouty arthritis appear as characteristic punched out cysts or deep erosions with over hanging bony edges.
  • This is called Martel’s or G’ sign.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male with frequent attacks of joint pain underwent an X-ray showing soft tissue swelling. The likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gout

 

Option A)

 

GOUT

 

  • During acute attack of gout, X-rays show only soft tissue swelling.
  • Chronic gout may result in joint space narrowing and secondary OA.
  • Tophi appear as characteristic punched out cysts or deep erosions with over hanging bony edges (Martel’s or G’ sign).
  • These well-defined erosions are larger and slightly further from joint margin than typical RA erosions.

 

 

Arrow shows Tophi in case of Gout

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Parathyroid adenoma. Parathyroid adenoma is a benign tumor of the parathyroid gland that can lead to overproduction of parathyroid hormone (PTH). Elevated levels of PTH can result in increased calcium levels in the blood, leading to conditions like hyperparathyroidism. While hyperparathyroidism can affect the bones and joints, it typically does not present with the sudden, acute joint pain. The common symptomatic osseous findings include subperiosteal and subchondral joint resorption, acro-osteolysis, the salt-and-pepper skull, the brown tumors, and osteopenia.

 

Option C. Psoriasis. Psoriasis is a chronic autoimmune skin condition that can also affect the joints, leading to a condition known as psoriatic arthritis. Psoriatic arthritis involves inflammation of the joints and surrounding tissues, often accompanied by skin symptoms like psoriasis plaques. In the foot, there are periarticular and subarticular erosive changes in the MTP joints and the IP joints. Subchondral sclerosis and erosions as well as marginal osteophytes are also present There is soft tissue swelling in relation to the involved joints.

 

Option D. RA. Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic autoimmune disease that primarily affects the synovium (lining of the joints), leading to joint inflammation, pain, and eventual joint damage. RA typically presents with symmetrical joint involvement and can affect multiple joints throughout the body. Radiologically, there is soft tissue swelling, joint effusion, juxta-articular osteopenia, bone erosions, joint space narrowing, sclerosis or osteophytes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given symptoms and the x-ray finding of tophi in the toe are diagnostic of Gout in the patient. 
  • The sudden and episodic nature of the joint pain, along with the presence of soft tissue swelling, is characteristic of gout attacks.
